rationale: Ictalurus australis occurs in eastern Mexico from Blanco River to the Pánuco River in southern Veracruz, Mexico. There is inadequate information however to make a direct or indirect assessment of its risk of extincion based on its distribution. More information about the species population size, threats and trends are required to assess it in a category other than Data Deficient.
habitat: I. australis inhabits quiet and slow-flowing waters such as lakes and river pools, as well as slow-current areas near river margins. It is an omnivore catfish that feeds on a wide array of prey, with variable diet throughout ontogeny, including detritus, small invertebrates, and small vertebrates such as fish and even birds (Ceballos et al. 2016, Contreras-MacBeath, pers. comm). The species spawns during spring and beginning of summer, nesting on sand and mud substrates, where both parents protect the eggs (Burgess 1989).
threats: The main threat faced by this species is overfishing, as it is highly desired and heavily harvested by artisanal and commercial fisheries for local consumption. Other threats include habitat modification and water pollution resulting from dam construction and agriculture, respectively. Furthermore, invasive species from the genus Pterygoplichthys may predate on their eggs and negatively affect its populations (Domínguez-Domínguez, pers. comm.).
population: Numerical estimates of population sizes and population trends for Ictalurus australis are unknown. However, it has been reported that the species includes few populations and with ongoing declines due to overfishing and habitat degradation (Ceballos et al. 2016, Domínguez-Domínguez, pers. comm).
range: Ictalurus australis is distributed in the Blanco and Pánuco rivers, southern Veracruz state, eastern Mexico (Ceballos et al. 2016, Eschmeyer et al. 2018).
useTrade: I. australis is primarily harvested and highly desired for human local consumption, with artisanal and commercial fisheries representing the main threat to the survival and persistence of the species (Domínguez-Domínguez, pers. comm.). It is not known to be used in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: The American Fisheries Society Endangered Species Committee lists Ictalurus australis as Threatened (T) due to an imminent danger of becoming Endangered in part or all its distribution range as a result of a decline in population size resulting from present or threatened destruction, modification, or reduction of the taxon’s habitat or range and over-exploitation for commercial, recreational, scientific, or educational purposes including intentional eradication or indirect impacts of fishing (Jelks et al. 2008). Similarly, I. australis is federally listed as Endangered ("En Peligro de Extinción [P]") in the Norma Oficial Mexicana NOM-059-SEMARNAT-2010 (SEMARNAT 2010).

rationale: This species is relatively widespread within western Africa, from Cote d'Ivoire to Cameroon. It mainly occurs in the Niger and Volta basins, and it appears sparsely distributed within its range and may be rare. Population information is lacking outside of the Volta basin, and the overall population size and trend is unknown. Within the Volta basin this species is declining due to the impacts of heavy fishing pressure, pollution and invasive species. This species is assessed as Data Deficient due to the unknown impact of these threats on populations outside of the Volta and the magnitude of the population decline overall. Research is urgently needed to confirm the population status throughout its range.
habitat: This species occurs in brackish and freshwater. It is benthopelagic and can be found in large rivers and their estuaries. It probably exceeds 165 cm.
threats: This fish has disappeared from areas mainly due to overfishing. In Ghana, the fish has not been observed for many years (E.K. Abban pers. comm. 2019). Because it grows to a large size, it is caught by fishermen before reaching sexual maturity to reproduce. Other problems that may threaten this fish include increasing agricultural activities around the Volta river and the consequent problem of leaching of agrochemicals into water, and increase in sediment loads. In some parts of the Volta, aquatic weeds may also pose a threat to the fish.
population: In the Volta (Ghana) it is thought to be declining and has not been observed for many years (E.K. Abban pers. comm. 2019), due to the threats of overfishing, agricultural activities and invasive species. The overall population trend is not known.
range: This species is known from the greater part of the Niger river basin, including the Benue River downstream from the Gauthoit Falls and from Ouémé and Volta rivers (Daget 2003).
useTrade: This species is harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: Research is needed to confirm the survival or disappearance of this species in certain areas. There are also many conservation actions that would benefit this species, such as monitoring and control of catches (e.g. legislation on fish size in trade and at the national fisheries level), advocacy on conservation benefits in fishing communities, and encouragement of community information gathering and reporting on species.

rationale: Gymnotus carapo is a freshwater fish species from Central and South America. It occurs from southern Mexico to Paraguay, including Trinidad, Argentina and Brazil. This fish is known to be a commonly used bait fish that also occasionally appears in the aquarium trade. The species is widespread and while it is possibly declining in parts of its range, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Gymnotus carapo is known to inhabit turbid, slow moving or standing waters (Kenny, 1995), and can be found also in shallow edges of streams (Loureiro and Silva, 2006). It is known to survive dry-outs in ditches, canals and small ponds (Kenny, 1995) and will be found to feed mainly at night, on worms, insects (e.g. odonate larvae), shrimps, fish (preferably small characids, e.g. Ctenobrycon and Curimata) and plant matter (Mills and Vevers, 1989; Møller, 1995). It is an oviparous fish (Breder and Rosen, 1966) and mouth brooding by males has been observed (Crampton and Hopkins, 2005), with males providing parental care in nests excavated for eggs and larvae (Crampton and Hopkins, 2005). This species is a neotropical teleost that swims by means of an elongated ventral anal fin and can distinguish between a `friendly neighbour' and a potentially `threatening stranger' based on electric organ discharge (EOD) waveform alone (Møller, 1995). The maximum size of this species is 76 cm TL (unsexed).

Gymnotus carapo are nocturnal predators of fishes and other small aquatic animals, and most are territorial (Crampton 1998).
threats: This species is largely used in professional and sportive fishery, as live bait it is preferred by higher predator fish species (Vergilio, et al. 2013), and is also used in aquaculture for production. Other threats to Gymnotus carapo, found in Argentina, include being parasitized (Arredondo and Gil de Pertierra, 2010) by three species of proteocephalidean cestodes (Gil de Pertierra 2003; 2005), and by the acanthocephalan P. omarsegundoi. While in the Upper Paraná River in Brazil it is parasitized by the following adult helminths: one species of proteocephalidean cestode, one undetermined species of Digenea, one undetermined species of Nematoda and the acanthocephalan Quadrigyrus machadoi (Takemoto et al. 2009; Arredondo and Gil de Pertierra, 2010).
population: More information is needed about the population size and population trend of Gymnotus carapo.
range: This freshwater species is known to be native central and south America, from southern Mexico to Paraguay, including Trinidad and Brazil but more specific information is needed about the geographical range of Gymnotus carapo. Within Brazil it is known to be found within the Corrego do Feijao, municipality of Sao Carlos in the state of Sao Paulo and also within Cima Lake in the northern part of Rio de Janeiro state (Vergilio, et al. 2013). From Argentina this species is known from the Paraná River and Colastiné River that is a tributary to it.
useTrade: This species is largely used in professional and sportive fishery, as live bait it is preferred by higher predator fish species (Vergilio, et al. 2013), and is also used in aquaculture for production.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for Gymnotus carapo are known.

rationale: This species is widespread in the western Atlantic Ocean and can be among the most abundant of reef species in the Greater Caribbean. As with many congeners, there are few countries that have multi-year data especially at the species level. Based on recreational CPUE in Florida and overall landings in the Gulf of Mexico and Atlantic US, there are currently few indications of major regional declines in the US. There have been declines in mixed-haemulid catches in Cuba and other sites. This species is heavily harvested in Brazil, but as in most countries, species-level landing data are not available at scales to evaluate three generation lengths of information (estimated at between 12-27 years based on differing estimates of maximum age). Haemulon plumierii is listed as Least Concern. Long term monitoring of highly fished areas will help future efforts to assess the species with data that fulfil IUCN criteria.
habitat:
Haemulon plumierii is a reef-associated species that occurs in subtropical waters (Cervigón 1993). Newly-settled and early juvenile life stages are encountered in very shallow hard-bottom and vegetated habitats throughout its range. Juveniles of this species are common in Thalassia testudinum beds (Cervigón et al. 1992). It feeds on crustaceans, small molluscs and small fishes. Haemulon plumierii uses seagrass beds as settlement areas and nursery grounds (Acosta et al. 2007). The juvenile usage of several backreef habitats in comparison to congeners is reviewed in Nagelkerken (2009). Haemulon plumierii displays diurnal migration related to foraging in some areas, leaving reefs at night to forage over grass and sand flats and returning to the reef by day for shelter. Various aspects of mixed schooling behaviour of this species have been identified in Brazil (Pereira et al. 2013). It feeds on a variety of benthic invertebrates including: shrimps, crabs, polychaetes, snails, sipunculids, amphipods, ophiuroids, tunicates and echinoderms; but also feeds on fish as well.

Male White Grunt in the US Atlantic peak in spawning activity from March through to June, a similar spawning season to H. plumierii from the west coast of Florida (de Silva and Murphy 2001). White Grunt south of Florida have been reported to spawn in August and September as well as in the spring off Puerto Rico; in Jamaica, maximum spawning occurs during March and April (de Silva and Murphy 2001).

In a study on H. plumierii from the South Atlantic Bight, 50% of the female H. plumierii were mature at 16.7 cm TL (Potts 2000). For male H. plumierii 50% were mature at 18.6 cm TL. In the Florida Keys, this species reaches sexual maturity at 1.5 years (Ault et al. 1998). Annual modal lengths for H. plumierii sampled from commercial landings in the eastern US showed a modal fork length of 26 cm (de Silva and Murphy 2001). Growth is fast during the first four years of life in this species, when the average fish size is already in excess of 80% of the asymptotic size (Araújo and Martins 2007). Maximum total length for this species is 51-53 cm, but it is more commonly around 30 cm, and the maximum published weight is 4,380 g (Courtenay and Sahlman 1978, IGFA 1991, IGFA 2011). Using a maximum age of eight years (Ault et al. 1998), generation length was calculated at four to five years, with three generation lengths estimated at between 12 to 15 years. Using a maximum age of 18 years (Murie and Parkyn 2005), generation length was calculated at nine years, with three generation lengths estimated at 27 years. Comparatively, White Grunts from the Gulf coast of Florida were of similar size-at-age as fish from southeastern (Atlantic) Florida but were smaller than White Grunt from North and South Carolina (Chapman et al. 1999, Murie and Parkyn 2005).
threats: This species can be subject to localized fishing impacts. Due to its high abundance and intermediate size, this species can be harvested in very high numbers using various gears. Early life stages can be a component of shrimp bycatch in many areas. As in many grunts, its use of very shallow habitats for settlement and early juvenile grow-out can expose local populations to impacts from coastal development (Lindeman and Snyder 1999). Early life stages have been recorded in the diet of the invasive and prolific lionfish (Albins and Hixon 2008). Adults of the species are closely associated with corals and a variety of direct and indirect threats may arise with increasing climate change impacts on corals and associated habitats (Ateweberhan et al. 2013).
population:
This species is locally abundant, the most widely distributed species of the genus in the western Atlantic and common throughout its range. For example, in a survey on mid-shelf patch reefs within Biscayne National Park, Florida, in 2003, H. plumierii was the most abundant species (Kuffner et al. 2007). This species was recorded with a high frequency (99% SF) and a low abundance score (ranging from 0.9 to 2.8 per sighting) from 18 sites in the Dry Tortugas National Park (Pattengill-Semmens and Akins 2002). During a survey of seagrass beds in the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary between 1999-2001, H. plumierii had a frequency of occurrence of 64.7% in the Gulf of Mexico side and 33.0% in the Atlantic Ocean (Acosta et al. 2007).

Recreational landings per boat trip from the Florida west coast were more or less stable at around four to six individuals from 1991-2013 (FWC 2014), and ranged in weight from a low of 133,828 individuals in 1986 to a high of 1,067,118 individuals in 2001, and at 823,982 individuals in 2014 (NMFS 2015a). Total commercial landings for this species in federal waters of the US Atlantic ranged from 4.9 mt in 1999 to 9.6 mt in 2013, with a high of 18.8 mt in 2008 (NMFS 2015b). The National Marine Fisheries Service conducted a population assessment of H. plumierii, which includes a specific assessment for the Carolinas and the Atlantic coast of Florida (de Silva and Murphy 2001). Spawning potential ratio (SPR) for H. plumierii in southeast Florida was estimated at 61%. The NMFS assessment concluded that by Federal standards the stock was not over-exploited by fishing. It was noted that the 1998 fishing mortality rate could be increased by a factor of three to increase the yield per recruit by 40% while maintaining the stock above 40% SPR (Potts 2000). In a 1999 stock assessment, the estimated average annual abundance varied around 1.0 million fish between 1994 and 1998 for the H. plumierii population on the Atlantic coast of Florida. Based on 1998 fishing mortalities, the static spawning potential ratios were estimated at about 32-35% (de Silva and Murphy 2001). Using data from the 1970s through the 1990s, Ault et al. (1998) estimated a SPR of 16%.

It is very common off Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico (M. Vega-Cendejas pers. comm. 2013. In Mexico, H. plumierii was recorded from eight stations in the Bocas de Dzilam Lagoon with 0.03 relative abundance (%N) and 0.02 biomass (%W) during a study conducted from 2003 to 2004 (Arceo-Carranza and Vega-Cendejas 2009).

This is the most abundant haemulid species in the commercial landings in Cuba. Mixed haemulid landings in Cuba over the past 40 years have fluctuated, but were relatively stable at 2,000 mt per year; then dropped to less than 1,000 mt in 2005 (R. Claro pers. comm. 2015).

In the Caribbean, three genetically differentiated populations of H. plumierii have been identified using mitochondrial DNA: 1) a northern type found from the Carolinas south to the Florida Keys, and in Panama City, Gulf of Mexico; 2) a southern form found in the Florida Keys, Yucatan, Belize and Puerto Rico; and 3) a third form found exclusively in Trinidad (Chapman et al. 1999). This has been long documented as one of the most abundant and widespread reef fishes in the Caribbean.  For example, a belt transect survey in eastern Saba Bank, Netherlands Antilles, from June through November, 2007, H. plumierii estimated a frequency of occurrence of 40% and the species was observed in 65% of locations (Toller et al. 2010). In Brazil, Araújo and Martins (2007) estimated that the stock was under low to moderate levels of exploitation in the late 1990s on the central coast. Average annual fishing mortality rates indicated instantaneous fishing mortalities peaked at 0.47-0.49 per year in 1992, decreased through 1995 and has increased since.

In the Abrolhos Reef system in east Brazil, the species was ranked third in abundance of haemulids surveyed with 0.9% of total biomass (Francini-Filho and Moura 2008). In the Rio Grande do Norte region, the species is commonly harvested in fish traps (Cunha et al. 2012).
range: Haemulon plumierii is distributed in the western Atlantic from the Chesapeake Bay south along the U.S. coast, Bermuda, the Bahamas, throughout the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea, and along the South American coast to Florianopolis, Brazil (Smith 1997, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Its depth range is one to at least 40 m (Lindeman and Toxey 2002).
useTrade: Haemulon plumierii is important in recreational fisheries and some commercial fisheries in the southeastern United States and of artisanal and commercial value in many other localities throughout its range. It is caught by hook and line, traps, spear and seines. It is one of the most important haemulids in artisanal fisheries of Brazil (Araújo and Martens 2007). It is marketed fresh and has been reared in captivity (Moe 1992).
conservationActions:
This species is within the Snapper-Grouper fishery management plan of the US South Atlantic Fishery Management Council and is included in the 20-fish aggregate recreational bag limit. There are recreational and commercial mixed-haemulid catch limits. It is also in the Reef Fish Management Plan of the US Caribbean Fishery Management Council, where landings are allocated by commercial and recreational sectors for mixed haemulids. The regional growth differences of White Grunt between the Florida Keys and off the Carolinas are important in fishery management planning in the southeastern US (Murie and Parkyn 2005).

Haemulon plumierii has been recorded in multiple marine protected areas in south Florida, Mexico and other countries. Examples include records from eight stations in the Bocas de Dzilam Lagoon during a study conducted from 2003 to 2004, located in southeastern Mexico in the central coast of Yucatan State, a natural protected area since 1989 (Arceo-Carranza and Vega-Cendejas 2009). This species has also been recorded from the Parque Nacional Sistema Arrecifal Veracruzano (Veracruz Coral Reef System National Park) and the Rio Lagartos Biosphere Reserve on the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula (Avalos et al. 2007, Vega-Cendejas and Hernandez de Santillana 2007).

rationale: This widely distributed species is common and abundant where it occurs in shallow coastal and estuarine areas. It frequently occurs as bycatch in trawl and saltwater angler, but is purposefully avoided for nuisance reasons. The population appears to have declined along the eastern U.S. seaboard, but the drivers are not yet well understood. Due to its wide distribution and stable population in the Gulf of Mexico, it is not considered to be experiencing significant overall declines. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs in turbid waters over muddy bottoms chiefly along the coast and in river estuaries. It prefers brackish marine waters and only occasionally enters freshwater and is also found in seagrass ecosystems (Motta et al. 1995). It is an opportunistic feeder on benthic crustaceans and small fishes as well as algae and seagrasses (Courtney et al. 2012). In the northern Gulf of Mexico, spawning occurs from May to early August. Following fertilization, males carry the eggs in their mouth for about a month. It may then carry the young larvae for a few more weeks until they are larger and stronger (Jones et al. 1978). It reaches sexual maturity before two years of age (Benson 1982). The minimum size of a mature female is 15 cm (Lee 1937), with males maturing around 25 cm SL (Merriman 1940). Adults are commonly reported at sizes up to 70 cm (Acero 2002).
threats: This species frequently occurs as bycatch in recreational and commercial coastal fisheries, however, they are purposefully avoided when possible due to their nuisance spines. There is no evidence that fishing bycatch is impacting its population on a global level. It appears to be declining in the portion of its range between North Carolina to northeastern Florida due to one of four causes: disease, harmful algal blooms, extremely low levels of dissolved oxygen, or water temperature. It is unknown which, if any of these are causing recent declines in catfish in South Carolina. It is unknown what other factors may affect the population, particularly the role that disease may play in continued apparent depression of this stock. Additionally, contaminants accumulated in muddy sediments, including metals, polycylic aromatic hydrocarbons and pesticide may directly affect this bottom-feeding species (P. Webster, unpublished report to South Carolina Department of Natural Resources). It is unclear what effect the Deep Water Horizon oil spill of 2010 may have on this species. It can suffer occasional mass mortalities during cold stun events in the Gulf of Mexico, however, the population in the Gulf is considered stable.
population: This species is common and can be very abundant in some areas. Hardhead catfish have been prominent in a number of mass mortality incidents in the Gulf of Mexico and appear to be in decline along the southeastern Atlantic coast (Wardle et al. 1998, SEAMAP unpublished data), especially during cold water events off Texas (J. Tolan pers. comm. 2014). The Gulf of Mexico population quickly rebounds from these mortality events and is not declining. As suggested by trawl surveys, abundance of the hardhead catfish in South Carolina experienced two drastic drops during the 1990s. Additional sampling along the Atlantic coast of the southeastern United States indicated that abundance remains depressed from North Carolina to Florida (SEAMAP unpublished data). Sampling conducted over the past eight years in coastal waters between Cape Hatteras, North Carolina to Cape Canaveral, Florida, indicate that this species may be in poorest shape in the northern portion of its range. There was also evidence of decline in a survey conducted in the Terminos Lagoon, Mexico (Villeger et al. 2010). Despite reduced abundance over the shallow coastal shelf, hardhead catfish are likely to be encountered by anglers in estuaries, through the surf zone and into near-coastal waters of the shelf. A true estimate of population size considering abundance through all of these habitats has not been calculated (P. Webster unpublished report to South Carolina Department of Natural Resources). Data from angler surveys and industrial trawls in the southeastern US and Gulf of Mexico likely underestimated catches of hardhead sea catfish, as they are frequently discarded at sea. Areas of high abundance are usually avoided as these fish are considered a nuisance (Muncy and Wingo 1983).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from North Carolina south along the U.S. and throughout the Gulf of Mexico except northwestern Cuba (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Observations south of Yucatan are likely Ariopsis assimilis (Castro-Aguirre in press).
useTrade: This is not a desired sport or food fish, however, their widespread distribution and abundance along the nearshore coast from southern Florida to western Texas cause them to rank high in bycatch of trawl and salt water anglers in the Gulf of Mexico. Industrial and commercial catches of this species are purposefully low because areas with high abundance are avoided unless suitable higher valued fishes coexist. It is usually culled from trawl catches because of low consumer acceptance in pet food products or as human food fish (Benson 1982). Commercial and sport fishermen consider it to be a dangerous nuisance due to its large spines (Muncy and Wingo 1983).
conservationActions: This species has no special protection under state or federal regulation. More  research is needed to determine stock identity, predator/prey relationships, and the drivers behind population decline in parts of its range (hypoxic events, disease, pollution, etc).

rationale: Notropis calientis is distributed throughout the Rio Lerma-Rio Grande de Santiago and the Panuco-Tamesi drainage basins located in central Mexico. By 2011, the species had disappeared from most of the sites where it had been recorded historically, representing a population reduction of approximately 82%. It is therefore listed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: Notropis calientis predominantly inhabits small streams, impoundments, and small spring-fed lakes within its native distribution (Lyons et al. 2004). This species can be found at altitude in excess of 1500 m above sea level (Gómez-Balandra et al. 2012).
threats:
The primary threat to N. calientis is habitat degradation as a result of urban, industrial, and agricultural pollution (Lyons et al. 1998, Lyons et al. 2004), as well as in habitat fragmentation resulting from damming throughout its range (Gómez-Balandra et al. 20012, Mercado-Silva et al. 2006). There has been considerable degradation in the water quality of Rio Lerma in the 20th Century from the pollution of major urban, industrial, agricultural and livestock wastes (Sedeño-Díaz and López-López 2007). While more detailed population data are needed to estimate the magnitude of decline, N. calientis is considered sensitive to habitat degradation (Mercado-Silva et al. 2006).

The establishment and spread of invasive species and their parasites (e.g. Cyprinus carpio and Micropterus salmoides) likely have an impact on the abundance of N. calientis and its close congeners (Contreras-Balderas et al. 2003).
population: Data on the population size and population trend of N. calientis are limited. There is evidence that the range of this species is contracting as a result of habitat degradation (Lyons et al. 1998) with associated declines in abundance (Lyons et al. 2004, Mercado-Silva et al. 2006). However, the extent of range reduction is unknown. A study in 2011 visited most of the sites where the species had been recorded until then, and it was not found in 85% of the sites (Pedraza-Marrón 2011). The number of sites visited correspond to approximately 80% of the known sites of the species, and it is assumed that, given the occurrence of similar threats in the remaining sites, the decrease would be at least of 80% in those sites. Thus, a population reduction of 82% is inferred for the entire population. The generation length is estimated between 2.5 - 3 years.
range: Notropis calientis is a widespread freshwater species endemic to México. It is known from the Rio Lerma-Rio Grande de Santiago and the Panuco-Tamesi drainage basins located in central Mexico (Chernoff and Miller 1986). Historical data suggests that this species was present in the Morelia-Cuitzeo drainage basin prior to 1985, but has since been extirpated from that locality (Soto-Galera et al. 1999).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures directed towards this species. The American Fisheries Society's Endangered Species Committee lists N. calientis as vulnerable based on the present or threatened destruction, modification, or reduction of the taxon’s habitat or range (Jelks et al. 2008). Research is needed to monitor population size and trends and the impact of current threats on the species.

rationale: Notropis marhabatiensis is only known from its type locality in San Miguel Spring southeast Maravatio in the upper Lerma River drainage, Michoacan, Mexico. Only a small population was found in San Miguel Spring in surveys conducted in 2000 and 2002. The species is severely threatened by water pollution from urban use, nutrients loads, sedimentation, and predation and competition from introduced guppies (Poecilia reticulata, Pseudoxiphophorus bimaculatus) and Oreochromis species. San Miguel Spring is surrounded by the urban area of Maravatio and suffers from intense human use as a washing place and recreational ground. In recent visits to the area (2004 to 2017), the species was not found and it is thought now to be possibly extinct. Based on the species restricted range, number of threats, and continuing decline in the quality of its habitat and the effects of introduced taxa, the species is assessed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct).
habitat: San Miguel Spring is highly degraded and used for recreation. The spring has growing aquatic plants of the genus Ceratophyllum and substrate composed mainly of sand and gravel with many boulders at the bottom of the pool and mud in the stream.
threats: Notropis marhabatiensis is threatened by water pollution from washing clothes by local people, nutrients loads, sedimentation, and predation and competition from introduced guppies (Poecilia reticulata, Pseudoxiphophorus bimaculatus) and Oreochromis spp. San Miguel spring is surrounded by the urban area of Maravatio and suffers from intense human pressure as a recreational area (Domínguez-Domínguez et al. 2008).
population: Only a small population was found in San Miguel Spring in surveys conducted in 2000 and 2002. In recent visits to the area (2004 to 2017), the species was not found (Domínguez-Domínguez 2009, O. Domínguez-Domínguez pers. comm. 2018).
range: The species is endemic to Mexico, where it is only known from its type locality in San Miguel Spring in the southeast region of Maravatio town in the upper Lerma River drainage, State of Michoacán. The species is thought now to be possibly extinct since recent surveys undertaken between 2004 - 2017 didn't find any juvenile or mature individuals at the spring (Domínguez-Domínguez 2009, O. Domínguez-Domínguez pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for Notropis marhabatiensis are known. It does not occur in protected areas. Research is needed to determine if the species occurs in nearby springs and assess its current threats.

rationale: The Whitepatched Splitfin is endemic to short sections of a river systems in Jalisco, Mexico, leading to two subpopulations: Río Tuxpán and Río El Tule. Both are threatened by water pollution through sewage from sugar cane mills, urbane waste waters, in addition to pesticides and fertilizers washed in from sugar cane fields. A large percentage of the drained area is used for sugar cane production, heavily impacting the fauna of these river systems and leading to an observed decline of EOO, AOO, quality of habitat. That, coupled with a small number of locations (2) based on the threat of pollution, means the species is categorized as Endangered (EN).
habitat:
The Whitepatch Splitfin is a bottom-dwelling and riffle-inhabiting species. As expected from this behaviour, Miller and Uyeno (1980) found a considerably smaller swimbladder than in the related genus Ilyodon. It extends only to between the fourth and fifth rib (versus to the first in Ilyodon). The fish live around and under stones and boulders of rocky riffles of generally clear streams, usually from 3 to 8 m wide. It is associated with abundant green algae on rocks and along stream margins, often with trees (including Salix) shading part of the habitat. The currents are moderate to fairly swift in the dry season, no doubt torrential during the wet summer months. Its habitats are similar to those of the North American darters (Percidae, genus Etheostoma) living among and under rocks in shallow waters. At the Río El Terrero, the long rocky riffles are separated by pools up to 8 x 20 m in major dimensions. Miller and Uyeno (1980) found the water clear, but quite easily muddied because of the silt amongst the rocks and boulders. He described the water temperatures on several visits to the Río El Terrero and to the type locality varying from 18 to 22 °C, with the air temperature generally higher (24 to 28 °C). The depth varied between 2.5 m and 15 cm (Miller 2005).

Observations of Köck et al. in March 2016 in the Río Contla about 100 m north of the HW 110 bridge at Contla revealed a very shallow habitat with water depths less than 30 cm and a width of 3 to 4 m, in the rainy season expanding to a width of about 8 m inferred from the pebbly shore. The habitat was structured with few big rocks and boulders in the middle of the current and a lot of gravel of different sizes, mud, sand and silt. Few patches of submerse vegetation (Characeae) could be seen in the more quiet parts of the creek. The current was mainly swift, the water clear. The water parameters about noon were: pH 7.6, carbonate hardness 3°, total hardness 7°, water temperature 22 °C. The quantity of urban waste was moderate, a discharge of polluted water close to the bridge let the pH raise up to 8.6 and led to the occurrence of nitrite (1 mg/l) and nitrate (25 mg/l) that were absent above the discharge pipe. Allodontichthys hubbsi was associated with its congener Allodontichthys tamazulae (in about the same quantity), Ilyodon whitei (dominant species, about 90% of the total number of fish), Poeclia butleri and Tilapias (species not determined). The top predator seemed to be Dobsonfly larvae (subfamily Corydalinae, family Corydalidae) with about 10 - 12 cm total length that could be seen hunting successfully twice per 30 minutes.

The Río Tamazula east of Tamazula de Giordano has a width of 5 to 10 m, depth down to about 50 cm in the dry season. The bottom is comprised of big rocks and boulders, gravel, silt, mud and sand. The water in March 2016 was swift to torrential, depending on ground and width, and clear to murky. The water parameters were similar to the ones from the Río Contla. The species was associated with the same fish as in its affluent, additionally could be found a few Xenotoca lyonsi. The embankment was comprised by small trees (probably Salix), reed and few herbaceous riparian plants; the main sections of the riverbank were free of vegetation. The quantity of urban waste was moderate, very close were viscous remains of burnt sugar cane that would be washed in the river when raining.
threats: Both subpopulations of Allodontichthys hubbsi are mainly threatened by water pollution, caused by non-purified sewage of sugar cane mills, by urban sewage of middle sized towns and wash-ins of pesticides and fertilizers used in sugar cane production. Large areas of the Río Tamazula valley are covered by sugar cane fields, and agriculture has a massive negative impact on creeks draining the surrounding mountains and running through the fields. Observations through surveys up to recent years (2016) suggest that the species is now restricted to river sections and creeks above sugar cane mills. Further studies are in need to decide, if its sympatric congener Allodontichthys tamazulae displaces this species in areas of ecological pressure caused by human activities. Surveys throughout the last decades suggest that the Tamazula Splitfin might be able to handle bad conditions better than the Whitepatch Splitfin, as it is the only species of this genus which still occurs at its historical localities. In addition to pollution threats, there is also the presence of invasive species (e.g., tilapia).
population:
There are two subpopulations: the Río El Tule subpopulation (encompassing fish from the Río El Terrero and the Arroyo San José de Tule with the type location at El Pozo Santo; Crucero del Tule), and the Río Tuxpán subpopulation from the lower Río Tuxpán. 

Referring to the Río El Tule subpopulation, a survey by Lyons in 1999 did not result in any specimens in the Río El Terrero and only a few in the Arroyo San José del Tule. The water of this river is polluted by sewage from a sugar cane mill at San José del Tule so this subpopulation may be restricted, if still extant, to very few river kilometres. 

Although there are historical records of a subpopulation from the upper Río Tuxpán, no specimens have been found in this river section since the late 1950's. Although surveys by Lyons in 2005 and 2010 and Köck et al. in 2016 revealed individuals in the Río Tamazula east of the town of Tamazula de Gordiano and in the Río Contla at Contla; there is a strong possibility that these individuals actually correspond to A. tamazulae.

Water pollution caused by sewage from a sugar cane mill in Tamazula de Gordiano is thought to restrict the distribution of this subpopulation to only 25 river kilometres along the Río Tamazula above the town and some of its affluents.
range: The Whitepatch Splitfin is a freshwater fish species endemic to the Mexican federal state of Jalisco, historically known from the Río La Trampa (Arroyo San José de Tule, type locality) and the Río El Terrero, both Río El Tule drainage, and from the Río Tamazula and further downstream from the upper Río Tuxpán, both names for consecutive sections of the Río Coahuayana, to approximately the town of Tuxpán. Furthermore, the distribution encompasses two affluents of the Río Tamazula: a nameless creek east of La Garita and the Río Contla. Though the Río El Tule is an affluent of the Río Naranjo (the name for the river section of the Río Coahuayana following the Río Tuxpán), the Arroyo San José de Tule and the Río Tamazula collection sites are separated by about 120 river kilometres and 40 km beeline. Domínguez-Domínguez et al. (2008) estimated a 65% reduction of its historical geographic range.
useTrade: This species is neither used as food nor traded as an ornamental species for aquariums.
conservationActions: The only conservation effort is an ex-situ breeding project run by the Laboratorio de Biología Acuatica in Michoacan University, Morelia, Mexico. No other conservation actions are targeting the Whitepatch Splifin.

rationale:
Allodontichthys zonistius is endemic to the Río Armería and one affluent of the Río Salado (Río Coahuayana drainage) in Jalisco and Colima, Mexico. A continuing habitat quality decline has been observed as a result of water pollution caused by urban, industrial and agricultural discharges and run-off into the rivers. The Armería river is highly polluted with heavy metals, pesticides, herbicides, and organic nutrients, and has undergone hydrological alterations as a result of over-extraction of water resources for agricultural and domestic use. 

With a best case scenario for area of occupancy (1,040 km2), extent of occurence (6,500 km2) and 10 known locations, the Bandfin Splitfin meets the threshold for Vulnerable (AOO: 2,000 km2; EOO: 20,000 km2; locations: 10), so therefore it is assessed Vulnerable.
habitat:
Like all other Allodontichthys-species, the Bandfin Splitfin lives in clear riffles over substrates of gravel, rocks and boulders. It may occur in depths up to 1 m in pools, but generally prefers depths of less than 0.5 m. During the dry season, the currents are slight to moderate, but turbulent during the rest of the year. The only form of submersed vegetation associated with this species is green filamentous algae (Miller 2005).

Harro Hieronimus (1995) observed this species in March 1989 in the Río de la Lumbre near San Antonio on the border between Colima and Jalisco. He described the habitat as a narrow creek up to 1 m wide and 30 cm deep, with the ground made up of gravel, sand, rocks and silt, easily to whirl, and lots of foliage. The riverbed was shaded by large trees; the current slowly running over several steps of boulders and rocks. He found the Bandfin Splitfin hiding under rocks and boulders. Other fish species found at this site were Ilyodon furcidens and Guppys (Poecilia reticulata). The water parametres at 12:45 on March 21 were: temperature 19.5°C, conductivity 560 μS, pH 7.2, total hardness 15°dH and carbonate hardness 10°dH.
threats: The species is mainly threatened by water pollution caused by urban, industrial and agricultural discharges and run-off into the ríos Armería and Coahuayana-basins. A recent study about the water quality of the Río Ayuquila-Tuxcacuesco-Armería system revealed mercury values above the permissible level and lead concentration close to the permissable level (Mancilla-Villa et al. 2017). The whole system is heavily polluted with heavy metals, pesticides, herbicides and organic nutrients. It has also undergone hydrological alterations as a result of over-extraction of water resources for agricultural and domestic use and, as a result of it, the river is often dry at the river mouth, acting as an obstacle for migratory species (Martínez Rivera et al. 2017). Sugar cane production on the plain between Autlán de Navarro and El Grullo threatens the stocks in this area through pesticides and fertilisers. An additional threat for the Río Ayuquila is urban and industrial sewage from the towns of Autlán de Navarro and El Grullo, and for the ríos Colima and Salado from the towns of Colima and Cuauhtemoc.
population:
From the affiliation to two separate river basins (Río Armería respectively Río Coahuayana), two subpopulations of the Bandfin Splitfin, (the Río Armería and the Río Salado subpopulation) can be distinguished.

According to the Río Armería subpopulation, stocks in the Río Ayuquila and some of its affluents recovered after the improvement of water quality from a sugar cane mill discharge near the town of Autlán, but these gains have been offset by population declines further downstream in the Río Armería and in rivers and creeks near Colima belonging to the Río Colima drainage (Lyons 2011). Furthermore, possible habitats in the upper ríos Ayuquila and Tuxcacuesco have become uninhabitable for this species due to dams (e.g. Presa las Piedras, Presa General Ramón Corona). Only one collection site above one dam, at the Arroyo San Pedro, is known. Due to its range and population declines in the lower section of the Río Armería, this subpopulation is regarded Vulnerable.

According to the Río Salado subpopulation, the declines observed in the Río Colima and its affluents can also be observed in this geographically close subpopulation. This subpopulation is much smaller, but includes two locations, so therefore it is regarded Endangered.
range:
The Bandfin Splitfin is endemic to the Mexican federal states of Jalisco and Colima and was originally described from the vicinity of Colima, probably from the Río Colima, Río Armería drainage. In following decades, it was also discovered in several affluents of the Río Armería and in one affluent of the Río Salado, Río Coahuayana drainage. Currently, its geographic range encompasses the Río Ayuquila (the name of the upper section of the Río Armería), the upper Río Armería to about its junction with the Río de la Lumbre (about 15km north-north-west of Colima) including the Río de la Lumbre itself, the Río Tuxcacuesco around its junction with the Río Ayuquila, one affluent in its headwaters (Arroyo San Pedro), and two main affluents of the Río Ayuquila (arroyos Ahuacapán and Manantlán), all from within the upper Río Armería drainage. It also occurs in the headwaters of the Río Colima, the Barranca de la Tía Barragana and Arroyo El Carrizal (Río Comala sources) around the town of Comala, middle Río Armería drainage. Due to a relatively recent stream capture (Lyons and Mercado-Silva 2000, Webb 2002), it has also been found in the Río Coahuayana system near the town of Cuauhtemoc, namely in the Arroyo Cardona, Río Salado drainage, and two of its affluents: the Arroyo Grande and the Río El Cobano.

In 2008, it was estimated that the Bandfin Splitfin had disappeared from about 30% of its historical range (Domínguez-Domínguez et al. 2008).
useTrade: This species is neither traded as food nor as an ornamental species for aquariums.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for Allodontichthys zonistius are known. A recent study (Martínez Rivera et al. 2017) proposes a monthly flow regime to ensure an ecological minimum flow of 4.5 m3s-1 to ameliorate damage to the Río Armería following the Mexican Standard NMX-AA-159-SCFI-2012. However, this hasn't yet been implemented.

rationale:
The Redtail Splitfin is a freshwater species endemic to the Mexican Pacific Slope, where it is found in tributaries of the Río Grande de Santiago near Tepic, state of Nayarit. The species is potentially threatened by habitat loss and degradation caused by sedimentation, chemical pollution, over-extraction of water resources, competition and predation from invasive alien species and anthropogenic modifications to flow regimes. 

Because of the combined effects of its current threats, its restricted AOO (12 km2) and small number off locations (2), this species is categorised as Endangered (EN).
habitat: The species inhabits springs and spring-fed pools, lakes, creeks and turbid rivers. The predominant substrates are mud, silt, sand, rubble and rocks. The Redtail Splitfin prefers depths of less than 1 m (Miller et al. 2005).
threats:
Main threats are habitat degradation, specifically water pollution and extraction of water for irrigation, and introduction of non-natives. (Kenway-Lynch et al. 2010). Xenotoca eiseni is potentially threatened by habitat loss and degradation caused by sedimentation, chemical pollution, over-extraction of water resources, competition and predation from invasive alien species and anthropogenic modifications to flow regimes (Jelks et al. 2008).
All stocks of the Redtail Splitfin are either extirpated or have become small and localized. The type location of the Redtail Splitfin has been modified into a fountain and included into an apartment complex with no fish remaining. The species was common in the Santiago basin, but not abundant in the Río Compostela. Decreases in abundance occurred at Río Compostela from 2006–2008 despite similar environmental conditions. In 2008, Poecilia butleri was more abundant than previously known, possibly resulting in increased competition between these two species.
population: Within the Río Santa Rosa drainage, the species occurs in moderate numbers in the Arroyo El Hijito spring area in Seis de Enero. In the Arroyo Compostela, numbers have been low since 2006-2008, due to increasing water pollution and the presence of Poecilia butleri, which became more abundant in 2008 (Kenway-Lynch et al. 2010).
range:
The Redtail Splitfin is a freshwater fish species endemic to the Mexican federal state of Nayarit. It was historically known from springs and creeks along the Río Mololoa around the town of Tepic, including the Laguna de Tepetiltic in its headwaters, from the adjacent Río Santa Rosa headwaters, both affluents of the Lower Río Grande de Santiago about 30-40 km away from the Pacific, and from the Arroyo Compostela including the Laguna de San Pedro, Río Huicicila drainage, 25 km south of Tepic. It probably only persists in a spring in Seis de Enero, Río Santa Rosa drainage, and the Arroyo Compostela. 

A 70% decline in the historical distribution range of the Redtail Splitfin was estimated in 2008 (Domínguez-Domínguez et al. 2008). However, this estimate included populations that were subsequently described as the distinct species: X. doadrioi and X. lyonsi.
useTrade: The species is not used for consumption but has been targeted in the aquarium trade for many decades. The surplus offered goes back to old collections, dating back to the 1950's and 1960's.
conservationActions: The only conservation effort is an ex-situ breeding project run by the Laboratorio de Biología Acuatica of the Michoacan University, Morelia, Mexico.

rationale: The Striped Goodeid inhabits thermal springs and their outlets in the Río Verde drainage, close to the town of Río Verde. The species prefers densely planted areas with depths of less than 30 cm. The known localities are threatened by groundwater pumping for agriculture and the increasing diving tourism in the bigger spring pools, while smaller pools are still used for recreation and agricultural purposes. A big threat occurs through non-native invasive species being introduced in the whole drainage. While the impact through cichlids (Oreochromis sp. and Herichthys cyanoguttatus) seems to be negligible due to different habitat preferences, Poeciliid species like Gambusia panuco, Poecilia mexicana, and P. latipunctata have a much greater impact due to competition for food. Especially in areas threatened by recreational activity, Poecilia mexicana quickly replaces Ataeniobius toweri. The species is categorized as Endangered (EN) based on its restricted AOO, EOO and number of locations (3), in addition to declines in habitat quality.
habitat:
Ataeniobius toweri lives typically in quiet water with little or no current. It can be found along shallow margins of lagoons, marshes and ditches, but also in creeks where currents may be moderately strong. It prefers depths to 1 m with very clear water, but can also tolerate murky water. Typical vegetation associated with the Striped Goodeid are species of Nymphaea, Scirpus, Juncus, Eichhornia and green algae. The substrate is made of flocculent silt, mud, sand, gravel and rocks (Miller 2005). La Media Luna includes an area with several warm springs and is located about 10 km southwest of the city of Río Verde. Water from two caves forms a catchment area or reservoir that the natives call a lagoon. The clear water smells strongly sulfurous and the temperature ranges between 26 and 30 °C (Wischnath 1993).

A habitat near Villa Juarez, surveyed by Köck et al. in 2015, is a system of channels about 250 m southeast of the El Aguaje spring (M. Köck pers. comm. 2018). The species occurs in narrow channels, about 0.5-1 m wide, under leaves of water lilies and occasionally between reed stems. It was hard to find at this locality and seemed to be rare. The ground was muddy with few rocks and roots, some patches of water lilies occurred and the water temperature was around 28 °C.
threats:
Brian Kabbes, Netherlands, visited La Media Luna in 1999 and pointed to the intensive application of the lagoon as resort and the usage of the outflow to water the surrounding fields. He also documented a partial destruction of the habitat as a result of this. Palacio-Nuñez et al. (2010) pointed on a similar situation. They complained about the tourism industry destroying habitats through pollution and poor waste management. In recent years, upcoming diving tourism has lead to severe damages of submersed and riparian vegetation. Anteojitos and La Media Luna lakes are protected as reserves, but groundwater pumping in the region may reduce spring inputs into the lakes and cause introduction of non-native species; this threatens the continued survival of Ataeniobius toweri (Domínguez-Domínguez et al. 2005). Observations by Palacio-Nuñez et al. (2010) detected a strong correlation between presence of Ataeniobius toweri and densely planted areas. Destroyed banks and competition through introduced Poeciliid species showed a negative correlation to the abundance of Striped Goodeids and Mollys (Poecilia mexicana); these are the main threats to this species.

This species is associated with dense vegetation, which makes it difficult to survey. Usually, the stocks are small, but those from Anteojitos and Media Luna seem to be quite stable (Lyons 2011).
population: There is not enough information about population sizes and trends. Usually, the stocks are small, but those from Anteojitos and Media Luna seem to be quite stable (Lyons 2011).
range: The Striped Goodeid, Ataeniobius toweri, is a freshwater fish species endemic to the Mexican federal state of San Luis Potosí and is part of the Río Verde fish fauna. It is restricted to several thermal springs and outlets South of the town of Río Verde, draining into the Arroyo Santa Rita (like the Lago Manantial de la Media Luna), a tributary of the Río Las Calabazas that merges into the Río Verde, and several springs and outlets North of the town of Río Verde, draining into the Río Choy and the Canal Acequia Gigantal, both affluents of the Río Verde as well. Few springs South of Río Verde drain directly into the river of the same name (e.g. Charco Azul). Domínguez-Domínguez et al. (2008) found a reduction of about 65% of the historical distribution range of the species.
useTrade: This species is not traded or utilised.
conservationActions:
La Media Luna lake became a state park in 2003 (Parque Estatal de la Media Luna) and protected area. It has an environmental management plan established by the federal state of San Luis Potosí. This plan divides the park into distinct zones, each with an assigned use. The multiple use concept is designed to protect the most environmentally sensitive regions, although strict enforcement of the rules is essential to the environmental management plan to succeed (Worfel 2016). Currently, it does not work properly, and no species targeted conservation actions for Ataeniobius toweri are being implemented.

Another conservation effort is an ex-situ breeding project run by the Laboratorio de Biología Acuatica in Michoacan University, Morelia, Mexico.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) because, given recent survey efforts and lack of records, it is inferred that it is either possibly extinct or if there is an extant population, it is very small (<50 mature individuals). However, additional sampling effort is needed before it can be declared Extinct or re-assessed under a different criterion.
habitat: It is a semi-aquatic species associated with humid montane forest streams. It breeds by direct development, although the site of egg deposition  is not known.
threats: Although general habitat loss through deforestation is a recognized threat, pathogens, including the chytrid fungus, are the primary threat to Craugastor species in the rugulosus series (Gratwicke et al. 2016). This species was predicted to be highly susceptible to the amphibian chytrid fungus based on anti-microbial skin peptides tests (Woodhams et al. 2006). It tested positive for chytrid fungus at El Copé, and it is now believed to be extirpated from the site following dramatic population declines (Ryan et al. 2008).
population:
This species was formerly reported to be locally common (19–68 animals/200 m; Ryan et al. 2008), but it experienced severe declines leading to a local extirpation at El Copé (Ryan et al. 2008, Crawford et al. 2010), El Valle (E. Griffith pers. comm. to M.J. Ryan 2008), and Cerro Campana east of El Valle (Woodhams et al. 2008). It was not detected in recent amphibian surveys of western Panama (Hertz et al. 2012). It was last observed in Cerro Bruja in 2010, and surveys after 2010 have not recorded the species (Panama Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019). In 2010, five individuals were collected and taken into captivity, but all individuals have since died (Panama Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019). 

There is a possibility that this species has been extirpated from its entire range, but further surveys are required (Panama Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019). Should the species still be extant, it is likely that it survives in low numbers, possibly fewer than 50 mature individuals.
range: This species is endemic to the western and central cordilleras of Panama, at elevations between 560–1,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from several protected areas, including Parque Nacional Omar Torrijos. Ex situ populations of this species were attempted at the El Valle Amphibian Conservation Center in Panama (Gratwicke et al. 2016) and in the United States (Ryan et al. 2008). These captive breeding efforts were not successful as egg clutches were infertile or did not develop to adulthood (Gratwicke et al. 2016).

Conservation Needed
If subpopulations can be located, the site(s) should be protected and ex situ efforts may be necessary.

Research Needed
Further surveys are needed to determine whether the species is still surviving (Panama Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits pine-oak forests, mesquite grasslands and disturbed areas like degraded forests that have been impacted by deforestation and livestock activities (Barragán-Ramírez and Navarrete-Heredia 2011). It requires the presence of lakes, pools or slow-flowing streams. This species breeds by larval development.
threats: The main threat to this species is habitat loss, arising from shifting agriculture and clear-cutting, livestock activities, and alteration and desiccation of waterways. There is also habitat disturbance impacting some subpopulations, caused by poachers of the monarch butterfly (Danaus plexippus). In 2010, in Mezcala de la Asunción, Poncitlán, Jalisco, one specimen was found with malformations in its extremities due to unknown causes (Barragán-Ramírez and Navarrete-Heredia 2011). This requires further research. Other threats include droughts due to climate change.
population: This species is relatively common, and its population is stable.
range: This species occurs on the southern edge of the Mexican Plateau from southeastern Jalisco to southern Zacatecas (Ahumada Carrillo et al. 2011) and the centre of Aguascalientes, northern Michoacán, southern Guanajuato, to extreme northwestern México state and most of Querétaro. It has also recently been recorded in the Marabasco basin in Colima, which represents its southernmost point (Rendón Suárez et al. 2016). It is found at elevations ranging from 1,500-2,500 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The range of this species includes a few protected areas like Sierra de los Agustinos and Cerros El Culiacán y La Gavia in Guanajuato, and Sierra de Quila and La Primavera in Jalisco. It is listed as "threatened" (Amenazada) by the Mexican government.

Conservation Needed
Additional land protection and habitat management is needed, since most of the species' distributional range is outside protected areas. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence is 126 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are known from three threat-defined locations, its population is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its forest habitat.
habitat: An arboreal species, it occurs in primary transitional forest, bamboo-dominated secondary forest, and isolated sections of heavily degraded forest (Penny et al. 2016). While it seems to be adaptable to habitat disturbance, it is a forest-dependent species (Penny et al. 2016). It has been found calling at night from leaves of bushes or trees at heights of 1-2 m above the ground. It is believed to breed in tree holes and similar water-filled cavities.
threats:
This and other cophyline species are highly specialised and restricted to ecologically sensitive transitional forest. While this species seems to be relatively tolerant to a degree of habitat degradation being found in forest edges and bamboo sections, the isolation of the small fragmented subpopulations seem to limit the gene flow and may affect the species' longterm survival in those fragments (G.M. Rosa pers. comm. March 2016; Penny et al. 2016).

A biosphere reserve has recently been designated in the area, but enforcement is lacking and forest is still under strong pressure from slash-and-burn (tavy) for small-holder agriculture, hardwood logging, and new and expanding human settlements (Penny et al. 2016). The greatest threat to amphibians on the Sahamalaza Peninsula remains, therefore, the destruction of forest habitat.

Furthermore, species in this genus have tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), but there have been no negative effects observed within amphibian populations in Madagascar suggesting the Bd strain has a low virulence level (Bletz et al. 2015).
population: The species is abundant at known sites, but its population is severely fragmented. Penny et al. (2016) found that the Ankarafa and Anahabohazo subpopulations show slight genetic divergence "indicating very limited gene flow between separated populations." Despite its relative abundance and degree of resilience to habitat loss, its population is suspected to be decreasing.
range:
This species was previously known only from the type locality in the Berara forest fragment (at 170 m asl) within the Anabohazo forest on the Sahamalaza Peninsula in northwestern Madagascar. Surveys between 2011-2013 have confirmed three new subpopulations 1) in the Ankatsakely forest fragment in Anabohazo forest, 2) the area surrounding Antafiabe village, and 3) Ankarafa Forest. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) has increased from 100 km2 to 126 km2.

Forests on the Sahamalaza Peninsula occur in two regions (Anabohazo and Ankarafa), are separated by 20 km of regularly burned and grazed savannah and scrubland, and consist of habitat fragments; a third region (Analavory) has been all but destroyed by uncontrolled burning in 2004 (Penny et al. 2016). Survey work at other sites in northwestern Madagascar (e.g. Manongarivo, Tsaratanana, Benavony) did not locate this species, despite having a distinctive call (Frank Glaw pers. comm. June 2009). These factors support the possibility that the species is restricted to Sahamalaza.
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The peninsula and coastal waters surrounding the species' range have recently been designated as the Réserve de la Biosphère du Sahamalaza-Iles Radama. Penny et al. (2016) noted that the Ankarafa Forest and Anabohazo forest fragments both receive protection and contain core protected zones, which seems to have halted farming activities, allowing the species to colonise newly vegetated areas.

Conservation Needed
The Action Plan for amphibians of the Sahamalaza Peninsula by Penny et al. (2016), calls for improved habitat protection inside the Reserve through the halting of human activity, especially detrimental agricultural practices, clear cutting of the forest, and even selective logging for hardwoods. This halt should be accompanied by education programmes to increase the awareness of amphibians and conservation benefits in local communities, improved community engagement (including employing local rangers to patrol protected areas), and alternative livelihoods. In addition, the Action Plan calls for the connectivity of suitable habitat to be increased through reforestation schemes.

Research Needed
Understanding of its habitat requirements and its breeding habits is needed (Penny et al. 2016). As is further research to fully understand the distribution, origin, type and virulence of Bd lineages found in Madagascar (Bletz et al. 2015).

rationale: The Chatham Mudfish (Neochanna rekohua) is endemic to Chatham Island, New Zealand, where it is abundant in three small peat lakes in the southern part of the island, from which it is found. However, there are additional, similar lakes nearby that have not yet been investigated and this species may be a little more widespread than is presently known. Very little else is known about the habitat or ecology of this species. It is nationally listed as 'At Risk - Naturally Uncommon', according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification scheme. The qualifying criteria for this assessment are that the population is stable, but the species is range-restricted. Due to the remoteness of the Chatham Islands and the location of the lakes in which this species occurs, there are thought to be no known or potential threats to this species or its habitat and it is therefore assessed as Least Concern. However, with increasing summer temperatures as the climate changes, there is a potential risk of fire outbreaks and secondary effects such as as fungal outbreaks. Currently, no information is available on what the potential impacts of these would be and further research is required, especially to investigate the cause and potential impacts of fungal growths observed on specimens.
habitat: Very little is known about the habitat or ecology of this species other than it occurs in peat lakes and is not associated with wetlands (McDowall 2004, N. Ling pers. comm. 2011). The lakes are very black in colour and as a result the water is very warm, especially in summer. Spawning is thought to occur in reed beds. The maximum total length of this species is 160 mm (R. Allibone pers. comm. 2014).
threats: Due to the remoteness of the Chatham Islands and the location of the lakes in which this species occurs, there are no current threats impacting this species. However, with increasing summer temperatures as the climate changes, there is a potential risk of fire outbreaks and secondary effects such as as fungal outbreaks. The water colour of the lakes in which this species is found is very deep red and is very warm. Numerous specimens of N. rekohua have been observed with odd papilated fungal growths on them, however no information is available on what the cause or potential impacts of these growth are (B. David pers. comm. 2014).
population: This species is abundant throughout the three lakes from which it is known (N. Ling pers. comm. 2011). It is nationally listed as 'At Risk - Naturally Uncommon', according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification scheme. The qualifying criteria for this assessment are that the population is stable, but the species is range-restricted (Goodman et al. 2014).
range: The Chatham Mudfish (Neochanna rekohua) is endemic to three small lakes (including Lake Rakeinui and Lake Tuku a Taupo) in the southern part of Chatham Island, New Zealand (N. Ling pers. comm. 2011). However, there are additional, similar lakes nearby that have not yet been investigated and this species may be a little more widespread than is presently known (McDowall 2004). For example, in March 2006, this species was detected in low numbers in a tributary of the Tuku a Tamatea stream (which drains from Lake Rakeinui), which was a new distribution record for this species (B. David pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation actions in place for this species. It is thought that all the lakes in which this species occurs are on private land, with no populations located within protected areas. However, the lakes are remote and development is currently unlikely (R. Allibone pers. comm. 2014).  Currently, no information is available on what the impacts of potential future threats (such as fires and possible fungal outbreaks due to increased temperatures) would be. Further research is required on these likely impacts of these potential threats and especially to investigate the cause and potential impacts of fungal growths currently observed on specimens.

rationale: Listed as Endangered in view of severe recent declines that likely are continuing (rate of decline over past 10 years unknown) and that has left only a small number of extant populations occupying a small fragmented area.
habitat: The habitat of frogs of the Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae complex includes sunny river margins, meadow streams, isolated pools, and lake borders in the Sierra Nevada. Sierran frogs are most abundant in high elevation lakes and slow-moving portions of streams. They seldom are found away from water but may cross upland areas in moving between summer and winter habitats (Matthews and Pope 1999). Wintering sites include areas near shore under ledges and in deep underwater crevices (Matthews and Pope 1999).
threats:
A petition to list the Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae complex as endangered cited the following threats: non-native fish introductions, contaminant introductions, livestock grazing, acidification from atmospheric deposition, nitrate deposition, ultraviolet radiation, drought, disease, and other factors (see USFWS 2000).

Extensive surveys in the Sierra Nevada clearly demonstrate the strong detrimental impact of introduced trouts on R. muscosa/Rana sierrae populations (Bradford 1989, Knapp and Matthews 2000). Removal of non-native fishes (relatively easy in some Sierra Nevada lakes) might easily reverse the decline (Knapp and Matthews 2000).

See Bradford (1991) for information on mass mortality and extinction of a population due at least in part to red-leg disease and predation on metamorphics by Brewer's blackbird; reestablishment of the extirpated population probably will be prevented through predation by introduced fishes.

Frogs of the Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae complex are possibly but probably not threatened by sublethal effects of low pH and elevated levels of dissolved aluminum (Bradford et al. 1992).

Fellers et al. (2001) documented oral chytridiomycosis (often indicated by oral disc abnormalities) in larvae and recently metamorphosed individuals of the Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae complex in the Sierra Nevada, where recent declines have occurred. However, loss of pigmentation of larval mouthparts does not always indicate chytridiomycosis (Batrachochytrium infection) (Rachowicz 2002).

Davidson et al. (2002) found support for the hypothesis that airborne agrochemicals have played a significant role in the decline of frogs of the Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae complex.
population:
Extensive surveys between 1995 and 2005 yielded only 11 occupied sites (Vredenburg et al. 2007). Total adult population size is unknown but may not exceed a couple thousand (generously assuming 20 sites each with 100 adults).

A precipitous decline in Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae appears to have occurred over the past 3-4 decades (Bradford 1991, USFWS 1999). For the Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae complex as a whole, Jennings and Hayes (1994) mapped many more extirpated populations than extant populations. Rana sierrae has declined greatly in the Yosemite area of the Sierra Nevada, California (Drost and Fellers 1996). In the Sierra Nevada, recent surveys indicate that Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae has been reduced to a small number of widely scattered, mostly very small populations (fewer than 20 adults) (Knapp and Matthews 2000). Surveys in the 1990s indicated that the rangewide decline in distribution may be as much as 70-90 percent (USFWS 2000).

Of the 146 historical R. sierrae sites studied by Vredenburg et al. (2007), only 11 sites contained frogs when revisited between 1995 and 2005 (92 percent extirpation rate).

The current trend (past 10 years) is unknown, but probably the decline is ongoing.
range: Historical range extended from the Diamond Mountains northeast of the Sierra Nevada in Plumas County, and from just north of the Feather River in the extreme northwest region of the Sierra Nevada, California, south through the Sierra Nevada to Inyo County, California, and east to Mt. Rose, northeast of Lake Tahoe, in Washoe County, Nevada (Vredenburg et al. 2007). West of the Sierra Nevada crest, the southern part of the range is bordered by ridges that divide the Middle and South Fork of the Kings River, ranging from Mather Pass to the Monarch Divide; east of the Sierra Nevada crest, R. sierrae occurs in the Glass Mountains just south of Mono Lake (Mono County) and along the east slope of the Sierra Nevada south to the type locality at Matlock Lake (Inyo County) (Vredenburg et al. 2007). Rana sierrae is now extirpated from Nevada and from large portions of the historical range in the Sierra Nevada of California.
conservationActions: Most occurrences are on lands administered by the U.S. Forest Service or U.S. National Park Service. However, occurrence in protected, pristine areas does not ensure population persistence.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because this species is probably in significant decline (but probably at a rate of less than 30% over ten years) because of a variety of threats, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: This species inhabits wet mountain meadows, sphagnum bogs, ponds, lakes, and streams, in open coniferous forests. It hibernates in mud at the bottom of ponds and in spring-water saturated ground up to at least 75m from ponds (Briggs 1987). It prefers quiet ponds for breeding and usually lays eggs in shallow open water. Non-breeding habitats are often more than 100m from breeding sites, sometimes substantially more. Non-breeding habitats can be streams in lower altitudes. It is not clear how adaptable this species is to habitat degradation.
threats: Observed declines in Lassen Volcanic National Park are apparently due to a combination of local factors, including (1) the presence of non-native predatory fish that have restricted available habitat and limited dispersal of frogs; (2) gradual loss of open meadows and associated aquatic habitats; and (3) loss of breeding habitat due to a five-year drought (Fellers and Drost 1993). Pesticide drift via prevailing winds might also have contributed to losses in California (Davidson, Shaffer and Jennings 2002). Introduced fish are implicated as limiting distribution in montane areas (Hayes and Jennings 1986; Jennings and Hayes 1994; Adams, Schindler and Bury 2001). UV radiation shows negative effects in experimental settings, but effects at landscape scale are unclear (Adams, Schindler and Bury 2001; Palen et al. 2002). Eggs are highly susceptible to the pathogenic fungus Saprolegnia ferax, which might be introduced during fish stocking (Kiesecker and Blaustein 1997).
population: In Washington State, hundreds of populations have been identified, but some of these are likely to be no longer extant, and others might be continuous with adjacent populations (Dvornich, McAllister and Aubry 1997). This species is very rare and possibly extirpated from the Mount Lassen area, California (Fellers and Drost 1993). However, a population persists at Trinity Alps, California (Bury 1973a; Jennings and Hayes 1994). Some declines might have occurred in the Oregon Cascades (Olson 2001), but there have been no declines documented in Olympic (Adams, Schindler and Bury 2001) and Mount Rainier National Parks in Washington State.
range: This species occurs in the Cascade Mountains from northern Washington south to northern California, USA. Populations isolated from the main Cascade Mountains complex occur in the Olympic Mountains, Washington; Mount Shasta and Lassen Peak area, California; and the Trinity Mountains, California (Stebbins 1985b; Nussbaum, Brodie and Storm 1983; Pearl and Adams 2005). Its range is generally between 665 and 2,450m asl, although some Washington populations might occur at lower altitudes. Its prehistoric range might have included much lower altitudes (Leonard et al. 1993).
conservationActions: Some populations are within protected national park and wilderness areas in Oregon (such as Crater Lake National Park, and the Three Sisters wilderness area), Washington (Olympic and Mount Rainier National Parks), and California (Mount Lassen and Trinity Alps). However, factors such as pesticide drift, UV radiation, and fish introductions are prominent threats even in montane protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because of a drastic long-term and likely ongoing decline that has resulted in a very small current area of occupancy, severe population fragmentation, and small estimated population size.
habitat:
The habitat includes sunny riverbanks, meadow streams, isolated pools, and lake borders in the Sierra Nevada, rocky stream courses in southern California. The species seems to prefer sloping banks with rocks or vegetation to the water's edge (Stebbins 1985). Zweifel (1955) observed that the frogs in southern California are typically found in steep gradient streams in the chaparral belt and may range into small meadow streams at higher elevations. In contrast, Sierran frogs are most abundant in high elevation lakes and slow-moving portions of streams. This frog seldom is found away from water, but it may cross upland areas in moving between summer and winter habitats (Matthews and Pope 1999). Wintering sites include areas nearshore under ledges and in deep underwater crevices (Matthews and Pope 1999).

In southern California, USFWS (2006) concluded that Rana muscosa requires the following habitat elements: (1) Water source(s) found between 1,214 to 7,546 feet (370 to 2,300 meter) in elevation that are permanent. Water sources include, but are not limited to, streams, rivers, perennial creeks (or permanent plunge pools within intermittent creeks), pools (i.e., a body of impounded water that is contained above a natural dam) and other forms of aquatic habitat. The water source should maintain a natural flow pattern including periodic natural flooding. Aquatic habitats that are used by mountain yellow-legged frog for breeding purposes must maintain water during the entire tadpole growth phase, which can last for up to 2 years. During periods of drought, or less than average rainfall, these breeding sites may not hold water long enough for individuals to complete metamorphosis, but they would still be considered essential breeding habitat in wetter years. Further, the aquatic includes: a. Bank and pool substrates consisting of varying percentages of soil or silt, sand, gravel cobble, rock, and boulders; b. Open gravel banks and rocks projecting above or just beneath the surface of the water for sunning posts; c. Aquatic refugia, including pools with bank overhangs, downfall logs or branches, and/or rocks to provide cover from predators; and d. Streams or stream reaches between known occupied sites that can function as corridors for movement between aquatic habitats used as breeding and/or foraging sites. (2) Riparian habitat and upland vegetation (e.g., ponderosa pine, montane hardwoodconifer, montane riparian woodlands, and chaparral) extending 262 feet (80 meters) from each side of the centerline of each identified stream and its tributaries, that provides areas for feeding and movement of mountain yellow-legged frog, with a canopy overstory not exceeding 85 percent that allows sunlight to reach the stream and thereby provide basking areas for the species.
threats:
A petition to list the Rana muscosa/Rana sierrae complex as endangered cited the following threats: non-native fish introductions, contaminant introductions, livestock grazing, acidification from atmospheric deposition, nitrate deposition, ultraviolet radiation, drought, disease, and other factors (see USFWS 2000).
