In particular, deforestation around streams is a severe threat (F. Vargas-Salinas and L.A. Rueda-Solano pers. comm. 2016). Due to its altitudinal distribution, this species is also likely to be vulnerable to the infection caused by Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, as well as to the pollution caused by the use of agrochemicals in agriculture (F. Vargas-Salinas and L.A. Rueda-Solano pers. comm. 2016).
population: It is abundant throughout its range within the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, but due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, its population is suspected to be decreasing. It can be confused with Cryptobatrachus ruthveni, which is only found in Serranía de Cebolletas and surroundings (F. Vargas-Salinas and L.A. Rueda-Solano pers. comm. 2016).
range: This species is endemic to the surrounding slopes of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, in the departments of Magdalena, Cesar and La Guajira, in northern Colombia, where it has been recorded from 250–1,790 m Asl (Acosta-Galvis 2014, Rueda-Solano and Vargas-Salinas 2014, A. Quevedo pers. comm. 2016, F. Vargas-Salinas and L.A. Rueda-Solano pers. comm. 2016). The EOO of this species is 15,907 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its range includes Parque Nacional Natural Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Las Aves El Dorado Reserve, Tayrona National Park and Jirocasaca Forest Reserve. No conservation actions are currently in place for this species.

Conservation Needed
Improved management of sites where the species occurs is required, including reducing agricultural runoff and halting deforestation along streams.

Research Needed
Studies on its population size, distribution and trends, life history and ecology, and threats are needed.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in X threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,796 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in four threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat due to agriculture, livestock, mining, illegal crops and agrochemical pollution from potato and onion plantations. There is also some evidence of previous population declines due to chytridiomycosis.
habitat: This species is found within leaf litter along rivers in páramo and subpáramo habitats. This species has not been found in disturbed habitat suggesting a low tolerance for habitat alteration. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Reproduction occurs by larval development, whereby eggs are deposited on leaves and larvae develop in streams."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Reproduction occurs by larval development, whereby larvae develop in streams. Little additional ecological information exists for this species.
threats: Although the current specific threats to this species are not clearly known, many congeners are classified as Critically Endangered or Possibly Extinct, so the effort to increase knowledge of this species should be made a priority (Bravo-Valencia and Rivera-Correa 2011). The chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, has been implicated as one of the main causes for the observed population decline. Other impacts on this species include mining, agrochemical pollution (potato and onion), livestock, impacts from increased vehicular traffic, large scale habitat destruction and the introduction of invasive rainbow trout into rivers.
population: The species was very common until 1995, after which there began to die in large quantities along the Cuisiana River (Rueda-Almonacid and Rueda-Martínez 2005). It is currently a very rare species. In 2004, only one individual was found. In 2006, students from Universidad Pedagógica y Tecnológica de Colombia found two individuals, one of which was found dead in the field. During 2006–2007, the species was searched for during several field surveys and was not found (D. Mejia pers. comm. 2016). There have been no surveys to relocate this species since 2007, but the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is found in the Northern Cordillera Oriental in the Department of Boyacá: Vijagaul, Pisba and Toquilla in Colombia (Rueda-Almonacid and Rueda-Martínez 2005). It is known to occur between elevations of 2,600–3,450 m asl (Bernal and Lynch 2008). Its EOO is 1,796 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Parque Nacional Natural Pisba.

Conservation Needed
Measures should be taken to monitor for the species and protect the known habitat. Captive breeding programs are also recommended.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It lives in terrestrial habitats, including temperate forests, semi-arid areas, walls, embankments, and slopes with small stones and sparse vegetation. Aquatic habitats in which the species breeds range from slow moving rivers to stagnant permanent ponds and pools; gravel and clay pits are also used. The larvae of this species frequently hibernate. The species can occur in suitable modified habitat such as traditional agricultural land, and even urban areas (e.g., in Barcelona).
threats: General habitat loss, largely to agricultural development (including loss of breeding sites), has contributed to the decline of the species in some areas. Fragmentation of populations might be a problem for the species, e.g. in Spain, Portugal and Germany. Certain populations of the subspecies Alytes obstetricans pertinax in protected areas of central Spain have severely declined and disappeared as a result of chytridiomycosis (Bosch et al., 2001; Bosch et al., 2000); a few specimens have recently been found again in this area (M. García-París and J.W. Arntzen pers. comm.). Additional mortality of the species through disease (iridovirus) has been recorded in Carris Lake, Peneda-Gerês National Park, Portugal (Soares et al., 2003); the disease might be non-native and have been transferred to the lake by an introduced North American predatory fish (Lepomis gibbosus). Mortality initially attributed to the bacteria Aeromonas hydrophila "red-leg disease" has also been reported (Márquez et al. 1995). Predation by L. gibbosus and other introduced predatory fish species, such as salmonids, is also a considerable threat to this species.
population: it is reported to be declining (including local extinctions) across its range, but it is still widespread and common in many areas (e.g., in much of France).
range: This species ranges from the northern half of Portugal and Spain (where populations are very fragmented, and there is a small Area of Occupancy within its Extent of Occurrence), through most of France, to southern Belgium, extreme southeastern Netherlands, Luxembourg, western and north-central Germany, and western and northern Switzerland. Populations in coastal Portugal west of Lisbon are extinct. It has been introduced to the UK, with several established populations. It occurs at elevations ranging from sea level to 2,400m asl (in the Pyrenees).
conservationActions: The species is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Habitats Directive. It is listed in a number of national and sub-national Red Data Books and is protected by national legislation in many of its range states. The species is presumed to occur in a number of protected areas. Further research into the current decline is needed especially into the impacts of disease. In Central Spain there is a captive breeding programme for this species, and some reintroductions have been carried out. In the Spanish national Red List is considered Near Threatened, and subspecies pertinax is considered Vulnerable.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 15 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat in the Donoso region of Panama.
habitat: This species prefers dry ridges in pristine forest where they live on leaf litter, tree roots or near the entrance of cavities under rocks or logs (Batista et al. 2014). The breeding ecology of this species is believed to be the same as it cogeners: it lays terrestrial eggs and tadpoles are transported by parents to phytotelmata, where they are abandoned (R. Ibáñez pers. comm. April 2016).
threats: Much of the existing habitat in the Donoso region where this species is found is primary forest, but it has been impacted by deforestation for agriculture by non-indigenous colonists and an influx of indigenous peoples from the Comarca Ngöbe Buglé (Batista et al. 2014). A copper mine is under construction in the Donoso region and will likely attract more people into the vicinity (Batista et al. 2014). Chytridiomycosis is an additional likely threat and Bd-positive animals have been found, but their susceptibility to the disease is unknown (R. Ibáñez pers. comm. 2015).
population: This species is moderately abundant at sites where it is found, with up to 15 individuals in 40 m2 (Batista et al. 2014). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is only known from a very small area in the Río Belén basin, Colón Province in Panama, between 50-136 m asl (Batista et al. 2014). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 15 km2.
useTrade: This is an attractive frog species with a limited distribution, making it potentially susceptible to over-collection for the pet trade in frogs (Batista et al. 2014). It is not listed on CITES and it is not currently thought to be collected.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has not been recorded in any protected areas. A captive assurance colony has been established at the Gamboa Amphibian Research and Conservation Center as part of the Panama Amphibian Rescue and Conservation Project, where it has been bred in captivity.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is required for this species.

Research Needed
Population surveys and habitat evaluation is required, as well as further research on its ecology and to confirm its reproductive biology.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, population status and ecological requirements."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">Listed as Data Deficient in view of uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence (EOO), population status, habitat and ecological requirements.
habitat: This salamander is only known from the type specimen collected at night shortly after a rain storm near the headwaters of the Río Chiriquí Malí. The salamander was found on the large leaf of an Araceae plant in an old clearing overgrown with grass and bushes adjacent to broadleaf, evergreen mature forest (Hertz et al. 2013).
threats: This species is impacted by habitat alteration for agriculture, roads and pipelines (Hertz et al. 2013). The type locality is 5 km north from an oil pipeline in Comarca Ngöbe-Buglé, which is one of the most deforested areas in Panama (R. Ibáñez pers. comm. April 2016). Its susceptibility to the amphibian chytrid fungus is unknown.
population: This species is only known from one specimen (Hertz et al. 2013).
range: This species is only known from the type locality in the Fortuna depression on the continental divide of Cordillera Central in western Panama, at 1,060 m Asl (Hertz et al. 2013).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The type locality lies within Bosque Protector Palo Seco and it possibly also occurs in adjacent La Fortuna Forest Reserve. 

Research Needed
Further research is required into its life history and distribution to better understand the threats and population.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: The species is primarily nocturnal; adults are most active during the rainy period between September and May, and is thought to aestivate during the driest and hottest months (Martínez del Mármol and Donaire-Barroso 2020). It is associated with springs and fountains, streams, cisterns and pools of either fresh or brackish water, and has also been found in road ditches and cattle tracks (Martínez del Mármol and Donaire-Barroso 2020). It breeds in these wetland habitats; females lay a maximum of 1,000 eggs. Terrestrial habitats of the species include maquis shrubland, oak and cedar forest, Nerium oleander scrub and ruins, and coastal dunes. Individuals can often be found hiding under rocks. The species can withstand some light habitat modification, and can occur in arable land (D. Donaire-Barroso pers. comm. 2020) and irrigation channels (Martínez del Mármol et al. 2019). It seems to be especially common around waterbodies in oak forest (Martínez del Mármol et al. 2019).
threats: The localized loss of breeding sites through agricultural development, the associated increased salinisation in lagoons, and the introduction of invasive fish are the main threats to this species. In the extreme south, within the Sahara, it is at risk from a reduction in the availability of water and subpopulations can be trapped in water cisterns which act as population sinks (L. García-Cardenete pers. comm. 2020). Recently a potential threat has been identified from infection with the invasive trematode parasite Euryhelmis sp., which appears to have been established in Morocco for at least four decades (Diaz-Rodriguez et al. 2018). However, it is not believed to be significantly threatened.
population: The species is generally common in both Morocco and Ceuta, most especially in sub-humid and humid areas. There may be a slight decline, particularly in the lowlands, as a result of agricultural development and increasing aridification (L. García-Cardenete pers. comm. 2020).
range: This species is present throughout much of the Mediterranean zone of Morocco and Ceuta (a Spanish enclave in North Africa). It is widespread both in and north of the northern High Atlas and appears to reach its eastern range limit west of the Moulouya River Basin, except for a contact zone with Discoglossus pictus in the Melilla-Nador area (Martínez del Mármol et al. 2019). A record from the vicinity of Targa Wassay represents a range extension of about 180 km to the southwest, into the Sahara (García-Cardenete et al. 2019). It might occur in the nearby Assaka/Noun basin (although surveys in Noun have failed to detect it - García-Cardenete et al. 2019), and is probably present in the Massa basin (García-Cardenete et al. 2019, L. García-Cardenete pers. comm. 2020). The species ranges from sea level to 2,724 m asl. (Martínez del Mármol et al. 2019). A record of D. pictus from the Saoura Valley in southwestern Algeria (Hughes et al. 1992) may represent D. scovazzi (Mateo et al. 2013).
useTrade: This species is not thought to be in the pet trade at present. Busack (1974) reports recorded imports of five Discoglossus pictus to the United States in 1971, which may represent this species or the subsequently resurrected Discoglossus scovazzi.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention. It is present in some protected areas.

Conservation Actions Needed
No particular conservation actions appear to be needed for this species at present, although monitoring of localized Saharan relicts may benefit this species.

Research Needed
Following the recent discovery of an apparently relict subpopulation in the Sahara, surveys are recommended to confirm its presence in suitable areas between Noun and oued Souss (García-Cardenete et al. 2019).

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered on the basis of its restricted distribution range and the presence of persistent multiple threats to the species. It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 208 km2 and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 168 km2. No individuals of this species were encountered at all the sites sampled in a recent survey (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018). The invasive hybrid cichlid Flowernhorn (Cichlasoma trimaculatum) has likely severely impacted subpopulations of this species. Lake Matano represents a single threat based location for this species as it has been significantly affected by a single introduction of the cichlid hybrid Flowerhorn. Besides the invasive species, the high level of sedimentation has also caused the decline in the EOO, AOO, number of subpopulations and the habitat quality of the species.
habitat: This small species, ranges in size from 12.5 to 27.5 mm SL, is endemic to Lake Matano, and here, it is syntopic with congener Mugilogobius latifrons. Habitat data are limited to observations reported in the scientific description of this species. This species occurs near shorelines of areas shaded with overhanging branches of riparian plants or thick growths of submerged Pandanus sp., in shallow waters up to 2 m depth over pebbles/gravel substrate (Larson and Kottelat 1992). Mugilogobius adeia remains close to, or seek shelter within, empty shells of the endemic gastropod Brotia gemmifera. Based on radiographs, this species appears to feed on short-spined gastropods (Larson and Kottelat 1992). In captivity, displaying males in courtship darken the colouration of the head and body, while the first and second dorsal fins become an intense yellow (Larson 2001).
threats: Two major threats to freshwater fishes in Lake Matano are the high levels of sedimentation, and the prevalence of the invasive predatory hybrid cichlid (Cichlasoma trimaculatum) - the 'Flowerhorn'. These two interacting threats result poorly for Mugilogobius adeia. The dark colouration this species renders it conspicuous against the light-brown sedimented waters of the lake, thereby prone to predation. The 'Flowerhorn' is likely to have also impacted populations of dark native shrimps and fishes in Lake Matano (Herder et al. 2012, D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018).
population: No individuals were encountered at all sites that were surveyed at Lake Matano in 2018 (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018). However, this survey did not cover all appropriate habitats for this species within the lake.
range: This species is endemic to Lake Matano within the Malili Lakes system in Sulawesi, Indonesia.
useTrade: The local people do not consider this an economically important species and is likely not utilised by them (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018).
conservationActions: Large parts of the range of this species are within protected areas. These areas comprise the waterbody of Lake Matano with a status of 'Nature Park (Taman Wisata Alam)' administered by the Conservation Forest Management Unit of Towuti (KPHK Towuti), and a large portion of the land areas surrounding the lake with a status of 'Protected Forest (Hutan Lindung)' administered by the Protected Forest Management Unit of Larona Malili (KPHL Larona Malili). Administration of these collective areas incorporates sustainably-managed zones for various human activities alongside nature conservation programmes. Despite the protected status, implementation of regulations appears limited.

rationale: Mugilogobius latifrons is listed as Endangered on the basis of its restricted range (with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,668 km2 and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 696 km2), and the presence of multiple persistent threats. The abundant, and widespread, predatory invasive hybrid cichlid Flowerhorn (Cichlasoma trimaculatum hybrids) likely caused the significant decrease in the EOO and AOO of this species. All three locations where this species occurs (Lakes Matano, Mahalona and Towuti) are also impacted by high levels of sedimentation which contributed to the decline in habitat quality. In addition, sluice gates along Petea River have resulted in population fragmentation of this species within the lakes system.
habitat: This species is known to inhabit three large freshwater lakes within the Malili Lakes system (Matano, Towuti and Mahalona) and their associated streams and rivers. This species typically inhabits shallower waters up to 50 cm depth with gravel/pebble substrate but are also found in areas with submerged wood, leaf litter and aquatic vegetation and some degree of wave action (Larson 2001, Larson et al. 2014).
threats: Two major threats to freshwater fishes in the lake systems are the high levels of sedimentation, and the prevalence of the invasive predatory hybrid cichlid (Cichlasoma trimaculatum) - the 'Flowerhorn'. These two interacting threats result poorly for Mugilogobius latifrons. The dark colouration this species renders it conspicuous against the light-brown sedimented waters of the lake, and they are thereby prone to predation. The 'Flowerhorn' is likely to have also impacted populations of dark native shrimps and other fishes in Lake Matano (Herder et al. 2012, D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018). Sluice gates along the Petea River could have also contributed to the fragmentation of populations within the lakes system.
population: This species was recently reported to occur in the lakes, as well as streams and rivers within the lake systems (Larson et al. 2014). However, this species was not encountered in recent surveys at sites within Lakes Matano, Mahalona and Towuti and associated river systems, with the exception of the Marara River. It should be noted that the recent survey did not sample all appropriate habitats for this species within the Malili Lakes. The Marara River is an inlet tributary draining into the eastern shore of Lake Mahalona. Areas where Mugilogobius latifrons were recovered are characterised by muddy embankments or areas with silty substrate, and shaded with riparian trees whose fallen leaves accumulate at the base together with other organic debris (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018).
range: This species is known only from Lakes Mahalona, Matano and Towuti and their tributaries, within the Malili Lakes system in Sulawesi, Indonesia.
useTrade: The local people do not consider this an economically species and is likely not utilised by them (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018).
conservationActions:
Large parts of the range of this species are within protected areas. These areas comprise the waterbodies of Lakes Matano, Mahalona and Towuti with the status of 'Nature Parks (Taman Wisata Alam)' administered by the Conservation Forest Management Unit of Towuti (KPHK Towuti), and a large portion of the land areas surrounding the lakes with a status of 'Protected Forest (Hutan Lindung)' administered by the Protected Forest Management Unit of Larona Malili (KPHL Larona Malili). 

Administration of these collective areas incorporates sustainability-managed zones for various human activities alongside nature conservation programmes. Despite the protected status, implementation of regulations appears limited.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened on the basis of its restricted distribution range (both the extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO) are 40 km<sup>2</sup>) as well as the presence of multiple ongoing threats to the species, especially from the invasive cichlid hybrid, the Flowerhorn. In addition, high levels of anthropogenic-derived sedimentation has caused a decline in the water and habitat quality. The number of locations could not be estimated for this species due to a lack of precise information on the species distribution and how subpopulations of the species would be affected by the numerous threats.
habitat: Habitat data are limited to observations reported in the scientific description of this species. Eight specimens were obtained from warm, shallow waters up to a depth of two metres from Lake Towuti, where it is believed to be endemic. This species attains 42.5 mm as an adult, and is relatively large when compared to congeners (Larson et al. 2014). Unlike other gregarious congeners within the Malili Lakes system, this species is considered 'shy' and was found hiding in crevices afforded by coarse gravel substrate (Larson et al. 2014). It is uncertain if this species is restricted within the confines of this microhabitat.
threats:
The major threats to freshwater fishes within the collective Malili Lakes system are surface mining, logging, increasing urbanisation, and modification of waterways from hydropower installations. The inshore habitats of Lake Towuti are particularly affected by log processing and pollution from the city of Timampu. The effects of mining have been less severe in this lake as it is larger and deeper than the other lakes in the Lake Malili complex (Hoese et al. 2015). Sediment accumulation due to these activities, and resultant light-brown water from the suspended sediment, renders this dark-coloured species conspicuous and vulnerable to predators.

This species is also likely indiscriminately collected for the aquarium trade but no published studies are found to support this observation. Other indirect threats to this species include commercial fishing activities within the area (Herder et al. 2012, Samuel et al. 2009).

Fourteen invasive fish species are known to occur within the Malili Lakes system. A potential threat could include the 'Flowerhorn', a man-made Cichlasoma trimaculatum hybrid now common in Lake Matano. This cichlid is opportunistic and has been observed eating the eggs of gobioid species (Herder et al. 2012).
population: This species was not recorded in any of the sites visited in Lake Towuti during a recent survey (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018). However, this survey did not cover all appropriate habitats for this species within the lake.
range: This species is endemic to Lake Towuti within the Malili Lakes system in Sulawesi, Indonesia.
useTrade: This species is reportedly already circulating within the aquaria hobbyist trade in Europe, although incorrectly identified as Mugilogobius amadi, but has not been observed in aquaria in Indonesia or Singapore, the latter a major trading hub for freshwater fishes (Larson et al. 2014, D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018, Z. Jaafar pers. obs. 2018). The local people do not consider this an economically important species, and it is unlikely utilised by them (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018).
conservationActions: Large parts of the range of this species are within protected areas. These areas comprise the waterbody of Lake Towuti with a status of a Nature Park (Taman Wisata Alam) administered by the Conservation Forest Management Unit of Towuti (KPHK Towuti), and a large portion of the land areas surrounding the lake with a status of P'rotected Forest (Hutan Lindung)' administered by the Protected Forest Management Unit of Larona Malili (KPHL Larona Malili). Administration of these collective areas incorporates sustainably-managed zones for various human activities alongside nature conservation programmes. Despite the protected status, implementation of regulations appears limited.

rationale: The species is listed as Near Threatened on the basis of its restricted distribution range (with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 762 km2 and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 368 km2) as well as the presence of multiple persistent threats. The abundant and widespread predatory invasive hybrid cichlid Flowerhorn (Cichlasoma trimaculatum) will likely contribute to a decline in the number of mature individuals. In addition, high levels of sedimentation are currently contributing to a decline in habitat quality. The number of locations could not be estimated for this species due to a lack of precise information on the species distribution and how subpopulations are affected by the numerous threats.
habitat: Not much is known of this species. It is reported to occur exclusively in areas with sandy substrate within Lake Towuti.
threats: Two threats can have severe impacts to Lake Towuti: the high levels of sedimentation and the prevalence of invasive species. There are an estimated fourteen invasive fish species within the Malili Lakes system. One such invasive is a predatory hybrid cichlid (Cichlasoma trimaculatum), the 'Flowerhorn'. These two interacting threats may result poorly for Mugilogobius lepidotus. The dark colouration this species renders it conspicuous against the light-brown sedimented waters of the lake, and it is thereby prone to predation. Further, the 'Flowerhorn' have also been known to eat the eggs of gobiid species in the nearby Lake Matano (Herder et al. 2012). Field surveys are necessary to determine if, and how, Mugilogobius lepidotus is impacted by the invasive cichlid.
population: This species was not encountered at any sites sampled at Lake Towuti during a recent survey (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018). However, this survey did not cover all appropriate habitats for this species within the lake.
range: This species is endemic to Lake Towuti within the Malili Lakes system in Sulawesi, Indonesia.
useTrade: The local people do not consider this an economically species and is likely not utilised by them (D. Lumbantobing pers. obs. 2018).
conservationActions: Large parts of the range of this species are within protected areas. These areas comprise the waterbodies of Lake Towuti with a status of 'Nature Park (Taman Wisata Alam)' administered altogether by the Conservation Forest Management Unit of Towuti (KPHK Towuti) and a large portion of the land areas surrounding the lake with a status of 'Protected Forest (Hutan Lindung)' administered by the Protected Forest Management Unit of Larona Malili (KPHL Larona Malili). Administration of these collective areas incorporates sustainably-managed zones for various human activities alongside nature conservation programmes. Despite the protected status, implementation of regulations appears limited throughout the lakes system.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because it may suffer a moderately rapid population decline during the next ten years, owing to habitat loss for subsistence agriculture combined with a potential increase in hunting pressure. If the rate of any future decline is found to be greater, the species may qualify for uplisting to a higher threat category.
habitat: It inhabits humid parts of lowland to high-altitude rainforest, occurring from sea-level to 2,000 m, and is at its most common between 1,250 and 1,750 m (del Hoyo et al. 2001). It is predominantly a terrestrial feeder, taking a variety of invertebrates. Breeding may take place in December-January. The nest burrow is 0.3-0.5 m long and is excavated in a sloping earth bank. Its clutch-size has been recorded as two (del Hoyo et al. 2001).
threats: The species's habitat is threatened by slash-and-burn cultivation (Du Puy and Moat 1996; del Hoyo et al. 2001), although it is not as affected as species that are restricted to lowland forests, which are under the greatest threat (del Hoyo et al. 2001). Increased hunting could seriously impact this species. Blood parasites have not yet been shown to impact the population but this may become a future concern for this species (Savage et al. 2009; Langrand 2013).
population: The population size of this species has not been quantified. Further research is required.
range: Atelornis crossleyi is found in the more humid highland areas of the evergreen forest belt of eastern Madagascar (ZICOMA 1999), from Tsaratanana south to Andohahela. It has a larger population and wider distribution than was once thought (A. F. A. Hawkins in litt. 1995; Morris and Hawkins 1998).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
It occurs in at least 12 protected areas (del Hoyo et al. 2001).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Conduct surveys to obtain data on density and thus a total population estimate. Monitor rates of habitat clearance and degradation across its range. Increase the area of suitable habitat that is protected.

rationale: This species qualifies as Critically Endangered because it occurs on one extremely small island and undergoes marked population fluctuations, owing to climatic events, reducing it to tiny numbers. Such fluctuations have led to extensive and strikingly low levels of genetic diversity, making it extremely vulnerable to extinction through exposure to stochastic factors including the accidental introduction of mammalian predators, non-native pest plants or insect species, as well as severe climatic events and disease.
habitat: It is found in dense cover near the ground, particularly around the shrubs Sida fallax and Solanum nelsonii on Nihoa (VanderWerf et al. 2011, MacDonald 2012), and Scaevola taccada and Eragrostis variabilis on Laysan (Kohley and Rutt 2012, Wilcox et al. 2013, Dalton et al. 2014). On Nihoa the main foods include small beetles, spiders, roaches and larvae (Morin et al. 1997, MacDonald 2012). The original, naturally occurring Laysan population was thought to have fed primarily on moths (Henshaw 1902), however, the species is thought to be a catholic feeder, feeding on the most readily available arthropod prey items (MacDonald 2012). Forthcoming results of research will include a comparison of potential Millerbird prey on Nihoa and Laysan islands (M.A. MacDonald in prep.). Pairs show year-to-year fidelity in specific territories, with nesting apparently correlated with precipitation and most breeding taking place in the winter months (peaking January-March), although the breeding period may be extended in years of high summer rainfall (MacDonald 2012). The translocated population on Laysan breeds from at least February through September, with a peak in spring-summer months (Wilcox et al. 2013). Nests are located in dense shrubs or bunchgrass, and two eggs are generally laid (Morin et al. 1997, Wilcox et al. 2013).
threats: The species exhibits extensive and strikingly low levels of genetic diversity as a result of recent severe bottlenecks (Addison and Diamond 2011). These may have been caused by climatic events, anthropogenic influences (impacts of Nihoa's prehistoric human population, and perhaps of modern introduction of nonnative plants and insects) or other stochastic fluctuations in habitat and consequently in population size. The Millerbird's extinction on Laysan in the early 20th century was ultimately caused by the introduction of rabbits and livestock, which denuded the island of vegetation (severe declines in the species's invertebrate prey and suitable habitat). On Nihoa, the population size is probably regulated primarily by precipitation levels, which affect the abundance of arthropod prey (extended droughts for example, are likely to have a negative impact). Severe weather events such as hurricanes may cause direct mortality of Millerbirds; a single severe storm could extinguish the entire population (USFWS 1984). Since the species has an extremely small range and has severely low levels of genetic diversity, it is particularly vulnerable to extinction through exposure to disease. Population outbreaks of the nonnative grasshoppers (e.g. the Gray Bird Grasshopper Schistocerca nitens) have periodically denuded 90% of the island's vegetated area, especially the shrubs in which Millerbirds nest. Outbreaks such as these may have been responsible for reductions in the bird population to well below 200 individuals in 1994, 1996, and 2005 (Latchininsky 2008). Fire is a past and potential threat (Morin et al. 1997) and introduction of detrimental non-native species, especially predators such as rats (Rattus spp.) is a permanent possibility. Nihoa and Laysan Finches (Telespiza ultima and T. cantans, respectively) may prey upon the eggs of Millerbirds, but since these species evolved together, it is unlikely to present a significant threat (M. A. MacDonald in litt. 2008).
population: The naturally occurring population on Nihoa was estimated at 489  ± 70 (SD) in 2010, 699 ± 78 in 2011, 610 ± 210 in 2012, 468 ± 166 in 2013, and 893 ± 303 in 2014 (Gorresen et al. 2016). The most recent estimate of the nascent population on Laysan was 164 in September 2014 (Dalton et al. 2014, Freifeld et al. 2016). Considering that the Nihoa subpopulation fluctuates widely, the band 250-999 mature individuals seems appropriate. This estimate equates to 375-1,499 individuals in total, rounded here to 350-1,500 individuals.
range: Acrocephalus familiaris is endemic to the steep, rocky island of Nihoa in the north-western Hawaiian Islands, U.S.A. It previously occurred on Laysan also, where the nominate race was estimated to number 1,500 birds in 1915, but became extinct between 1916 and 1923. On Nihoa, monitoring methods used from 1967 to 2014, and data recorded intermittently since the late 1960s, did not yield precise population estimates or trends for this species (Morin et al. 1997, Gorresen et al. 2012, Gorresen et al. 2016). However, the existing data do suggest that Millerbird numbers on Nihoa have experienced pronounced fluctuations and have likely ranged between fewer than 50 and more than 800 individuals (Marshall et al. 2012, Gorresen et al. 2016). The last estimates using these methods were 468 ± 166 (SD) individuals in September 2013 and 893 ± 303 (SD) in September 2014 (Gorresen et al. 2016). Wide fluctuations have had a significant impact on the genetic diversity of the remaining population, with the effective number of breeders being estimated as between 5 and 13 individuals (using samples collected in 2007 and 2009 [Addison et al. 2011]). The vegetated area of Nihoa is just 61.9 ha (86% of the island; Gorresen et al. 2012), and Millerbirds are distributed relatively evenly across the island, with some areas of slightly higher densities (MacDonald 2012, Gorresen et al. 2016). Conservation translocations were undertaken in September 2011 and August 2012, when a total of 50 Millerbirds were moved from Nihoa to Laysan, a distance of 1,037 km (Freifeld et al. 2016). The birds began breeding successfully within six months of the first release. Based on post-release monitoring through 2014, the nascent population on Laysan was estimated at 164 birds (Dalton et al. 2014, Freifeld et al. 2016).
conservationActions:
Conservation and Research Actions Underway
Nihoa is part of the Hawaiian Islands National Wildlife Refuge and Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument (H. Freifeld in litt. 2010). Legal access is controlled by a permit system that restricts access to biologists, other researchers, and native Hawaiian cultural practitioners. Strict biosecurity protocols are followed to ensure that legal visitors do not accidentally introduce new species via seeds, eggs or arthropods travelling on clothes and equipment. Visiting scientists make efforts to control alien plants by hand pulling and other methods (eg. Plentovich et al. 2014). A scoping document for translocations was produced in 2007, identifying Laysan, Kure and Lisianski as the most suitable islands on the basis of island size, elevation and a lack of predators (Morin and Conant 2007). Development of detailed translocation, release, and monitoring methods were finalized in 2011 (Farmer et al. 2011) and two successful translocations to Laysan in 2011 and 2012 resulted in a nascent population there, last estimated at 164 birds (Freifeld et al. 2016). The population will continue to be monitored and the data used to determine population persistence and growth. New, more rigorous population monitoring methods were introduced on Nihoa in recent years (Gorresen et al. 2012, Gorresen et al. 2016); these are expected to yield estimates of total numbers with improved confidence and, if monitoring is done annually, early detection of significant trends. 

Conservation and Research Actions Proposed

Continue monitoring millerbirds on Nihoa and Laysan. Monitoring on Laysan is particularly important to document vital rates, dispersal, and habitat use, and the role of these in population persistence. Continued study of the reintroduced population on Laysan is essential to inform conservation translocations of this and other Hawaiian passerines in the future. However, monitoring and study on Laysan has become far more challenging since the closure of the long-term, year-round USFWS field camp on the island in 2013. Continue to monitor Nihoa for the highly invasive plant Cenchrous echinatus that was re-discovered in September 2011, and continue to monitor and manage invasive alien plants on Laysan (e.g., Morin and Conant 1998). Ensure strict adherence to quarantine protocols to prevent further accidental introductions of alien species. Carry out additional translocations to establish populations on other islands as appropriate (S. Conant in litt. 2008, Freifeld et al. 2016).

rationale: Although this species may have a restricted range, it is not believed to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (extent of occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2</sup> combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). The population trend is currently considered to be stable, and hence the species does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over ten years or three generations). The population size has not been quantified, but it is not believed to approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in ten years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern, although further information regarding population trends across its range may mean this species warrants uplisting in the future.
threats: This species may be affected by nest predation by species such as Black Rat (Rattus rattus), Brown Lemur (Eulemur fulvus) and Mongoose Lemur (E. mongoz). Additionally, cyclones, mangrove destruction, disease, poisoning and competition with House Sparrows (Passer domesticus) may be an issue for this species, particularly on Mayotte (Safford and Louette 2013).
population: On Mayotte, the population may number 5,000-10,000 individuals (Rocamora 2004), roughly equivalent to 3,333-6,667 mature individuals. With a density of <27 males per km2 on Mohéli, and lower densities on Anjouan (Safford and Louette 2013), the population is suspected to fall in the range of 10,000-19,999 mature individuals.

rationale: Graptemys barbouri has been assessed as Vulnerable due to an inferred population decline resulting from overharvesting, habitat degradation, predation and disease. The global population is estimated to be between 1,000 and 10,000 individuals, restricted to a maximum of 20 subpopulations. Graptemys barbouri has been described as reasonably abundant in parts of its range but rare in others. Long-term population comparisons may be interpreted as indicating stable or declining populations, but the large numbers historically collected are no longer encountered. The species may qualify as Endangered if better data are available.
habitat:
Graptemys barbouri favours sections of free-flowing rivers with limestone outcrops, which support good populations of freshwater snails, but use of silty channels is also widespread. (Ewert et al. 2006).The species is essentially carnivorous, with juveniles and males feeding on a variety of insects and small snails, whereas larger females shift to a diet of predominantly freshwater snails with some bivalves also taken. (Ewert et al. 2006).

Females require many years (possibly 14–20 years) to reach maturity at 20 cm carapace length (CL) and 1 kg weight; males mature in three to four years at about 8 cm CL. Females reach their maximum size (largest recorded – 330 mm CL, 3.3 kg) by the age of about 24 years. Males reach only 130 mm CL at about 200 g. Corresponding to the different age to reach maturity, population sex ratios have been recorded as 67–78% males. Hatchlings measure 30–38 mm and weigh up to 13 g (Ewert et al. 2006).

Females have a prolonged nesting season (late April to early August) with rather small clutch size (usually 7–10 eggs/clutch, extremes 3–15) and may produce three to five clutches per year, for an annual reproductive output of 25–40 eggs (Ewert et al. 2006). Nest predation rates are substantial, mainly by raccoons but also fish crows (Ewert et al. 2006).
threats:
Graptemys barbouri is threatened by habitat degradation, overharvesting and predation. Local harvesting is thought to continue along the Chipola River (Ewert et al. 2006). Some shooting is thought to still continue.

Channel modification, dredging, barge traffic and pollution threaten its riverine habitat. Increasingly, overgrowth of sandy spoil mound sites for nesting is changing the spatial distribution of nests, with nesting sites becoming ever more clumped, and removal of dead trees or 'snags' removes basking sites (Ewert et al. 2006). Demand for water from the rivers it inhabits is substantial and likely to increase in the future. Few superfund polluted sites are located within or immediately connected to G. barbouri habitat, and the potential of a major industrial spill affecting a significant section of the total population of G. barbouri cannot be discounted. (Ewert et al. 2006).

Eggs and young are heavily predated by raccoons and fish crows, affecting recruitment. Raccoons also kill nesting adult females. To what extent raccoon and fish crow populations near the nesting sites of G. barbouri are subsidized by humans remains unknown (Ewert et al. 2006).

Parts of the Flint River population have been affected by a sometimes-fatal disease condition of unknown etiology.

In the Choctawhatchee River system there is indication of introgressive hybridization with G. ernsti, which could locally deplete G. barbouri as a pure form. (Ewert et al. 2006).
population:
Graptemys barbouri was considered the fourth rarest Graptemys based on extensive basking surveys (Lindeman pers. comm. 2009).

Moler (1986) compared his population survey along the Chipola River to Carr's (1952) observations, and concluded that population trends in the 45 years since the observations by Carr was as compatible with a stable population as with a decline. However, compared to encounter rates of 68.3 turtles/km of river by Sanderson in 1974 during repeated sampling of a 5.65 km section (total of 386 individuals), sighting rates of 2.64 (average) to 5.66 turtles/km by 1986 suggest a substantial decline at least locally. Cagle (1952) collected 393 individuals from an unspecified section of this river.

Numbers along a surveyed section of the Apalachicola River estimate numbers of 350–500 individuals (Zappalorti in Ewert et al. 2006), with Choctawhatchee River estimates a minimum of 250 individuals in the Florida stretch with the highest recorded density as 7.1 turtles/km.

The population of G. barbouri is estimated to range between 1,000 and 10,000 individuals, found in 1–20 subpopulations (NatureServe 2006). This species is reportedly abundant in parts of its range, such as the Chipola, Apalachicola, and Flint Rivers, while it is scarce in others. NatureServe (2006) describe the population's short term trend as “declining to stable”.
range: Graptemys barbouri inhabits the Apalachicola River system and nearby systems of Florida, Georgia, and Alabama in the southeastern United States, including the Chattahoochee river system as far north as Stewart County, GA, the Flint River north to Meriwether Coounty, GA, the Chipola River, and the Choctawhatchee and Pea River systems as far as Geneva Coouty, AL (Iverson 1992, Bonin et al. 2006, Ewert et al. 2006).
useTrade: Graptemys barbouri is harvested for food and for the pet trade. Local harvesting is thought to continue along the Chipola River (Ewert et al. 2006). Some shooting is thought to still continue.
conservationActions:
Previously Graptemys barbouri was assessed by IUCN (in 1996) as LC/nt under the version 2.3 criteria; as G2, or Vulnerable, by NatureServe in 1996; as G2 (Imperiled) at both global and State level by the Florida Natural Areas Inventory; and as a Species of Special Concern in Florida. Graptemys barbouri is included in CITES Appendix III (United States) since 14th June 2006.

Graptemys barbouri is prohibited from most forms of commercial exploitation in Alabama, Florida and Georgia, and only Florida allows take of up to two individuals for personal use.

Management of subsidized / elevated raccoon and fish crow populations is a challenging prospect but should be considered (Ewert et al. 2006).

Future river management, including commercial barge traffic, recreational boating, snag removal, sand dredging and water usage, and waterfront residential developments, are generally beyond the scope of turtle conservation but turtles should at least be integrated into management plans and practices, and a few specific sites warrant protected status (Ewert et al. 2006).

Research on the population and harvest levels is recommended to identify the rate of past and current decline,

Genetic evaluation of the Choctawhatchee map turtles is needed. (Ewert et al. 2006).

rationale: Previously flagged as Possibly Extinct, a single, small relict subpopulation of this species was discovered in 2008. It is still listed as Critically Endangered, but it is no longer flagged as Possibly extinct. Its area of occupancy (AOO) is 4 km<sup>2</sup>, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 31 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in a single threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in its AOO, EOO, the extent and quality of its habitat, and in the number of mature individuals. The species persists in a single, small, threatened relic population.
habitat: It lives in mid- to high-elevation humid montane forest (Coloma 1995). Individuals have also been recorded on the edge of ditches and irrigation canals. It lays its eggs on the ground, and males carry the eggs to small streams for development.
threats: The current primary threat to this species is habitat destruction and degradation due to agriculture, clear cutting, and human settlement; virtually no habitat remains in this species' historical range. The severe declines seen in this species could have been caused in part by chytridiomycosis, as other species occurring in the same localities where this species used to occur have been affected by the disease (Bustamante et al. 2005). The species may also be threatened by eruptions of Volcan Cotopaxi, which became active in 2015.
population: It used to be a widespread and common species, but it has been extirpated from most of its historical range. Bustamante (2002) provides data of its absence at Bosque Protector Cashca Totoras (Provincia Bolívar), where it used to be a common frog and where there are records of chytridiomycosis in other amphibian species. Until a relict subpopulation was discovered in 2008, in a valley nearby Quito, in the area of Cotopaxi volcano (Ron et al. 2011, Coloma et al. 2012), the last known record was from the Cashca Totoras Protective Forest (Bolívar Province) in 1990 (Ron 2018). The town in the area of Cotopaxi volcano has been visited frequently since its rediscovery; tadpoles and juveniles are generally seen (Frenkel et al. 2019). During a visit in November 2019, males were also heard singing (P. Pintanel pers. obs. In: Frenkel et al. 2019). It is possible that other undetected relict subpopulations might still survive. Due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, the remaining population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was known from over 10 localities from the inter-Andean valleys of Guayllabamba, Toachi, Chimbo, and Cañar, and on the western slopes of the Andes in northern and central Ecuador, where it occupied areas between 1,500 and 3,800 m asl. As of 2019, the species is known only from one location near Quito in the region of Cotopaxi volcano (Coloma et al. 2012). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 31 km2 and its area of occupancy (AOO) is 4 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The historical distribution range of the species overlaps with Reserva Ecológica Los Illinizas, Reserva Geobotánica Pululahua, and Reserva de Producción Faunística Chimborazo. The only known extant subpopulation is not protected. Efforts to reproduce it in captivity in the Balsa de los Sapos (PUCE) have been unsuccessful despite having kept colonies in captivity for more than 10 years (Frenkel et al. 2019).

Conservation Needed
Protection of the species' habitat is needed, as is a recovery plan that could include possible reintroduction programs to establish assurance populations.

Research Needed
Further research is required to establish the effect of chytrid on this species, to locate any remaining subpopulations, and ongoing monitoring of the only known subpopulation is required.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Near Threatened because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is XXX km2, it occurs in XXX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}" data-sheets-textstyleruns="{"1":0}[null,68,{"5":1}]{"1":71}[null,90,{"5":1}]{"1":93}">Listed as Near Threatened because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 20,476 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in nearly 10 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Tropical Andes of Bolivia and Argentina, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: It occurs on the ground of steep slopes and mountain streams of upland areas dominated by an evergreen shaded forest (Vaira 2012). Reproductive activity is in late winter and early spring from August to October and eggs are laid in rocky mountain streams (Haad et al. 2014, Pereyra et al. 2015).
threats: Selective logging and clear-cutting of primary forests are the main threat to this species, although it is also being affected by the introduction of predatory fish (salmonids) and the alteration of watersheds (Lavilla and Heatwole 2010). In Bolivia, the species is threatened by deforestation for small and large-scale cattle pastures and agricultural crops, as well as, road development and oil exploration (Bolivian Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). Pereyra et al. (2015) reported infection of egg clutches by water moulds of the family Saprolegniaceae.
population: The population appears to be stable (M.S. Akmentins and M. Vaira pers. comm. September 2017, Bolivian Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Adults, tadpoles and metamorphic individuals are locally abundant in many subpopulations of the Yungas Andean forests ecoregion in Jujuy and Salta provinces in Argentina (Haad et al. 2014, Pereyra et al. 2015, M.S. Akmentins and M. Vaira pers. comm. September 2017).
range: This species occurs in the northern portion of the Yungas Andean forest ecoregion of Salta and Jujuy Provinces, Argentina (Vaira et al. 2012), and in the Tucuman-Bolivian Forest ecoregion of Tarija department, Bolivia (Muñoz and Aguayo 2009, Bolivian Red List Assessment Workshop 2019), from 550–1,700 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 20,476 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Argentina, it occurs in Parque Nacional Calilegua in Jujuy province, and Parque Nacional Baritú and Reserva Nacional Nogalar de los Toldos in Salta province (Vaira et al. 2012, M.S. Akmentins and M. Vaira pers. comm. September 2017). Some subpopulations in Bolivia have been recorded from Reserva Nacional de Flora y Fauna Tariquia and Alarachi Private Reserve (Muñoz and Aguayo 2009) and Parque Nacional Aguaragüe (J. Aparicio and R. Aguayo pers. comm. September 2019).

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population size and trends is recommended.

rationale: This is a widely distributed euryhaline and schooling species endemic to the Caspian Sea. Population information is limited for this species and data are mostly available from catch records off Iran where catches have increased overall in the most recent 10 years available (2008 - 2017) but have stabilized in the most recent five years. Since the accidental introduction of Mnemiopsis leidyi in the late 1990s, the abundance of C. engrauliformis and C. grimmi has declined substantially and this species has become the most abundant species of Kilka in the Caspian Sea. This species is not as negatively impacted by M. leidyi as the other two species of Kilka because it has a slightly different ecology, such as spawning seasonality and a wider diet preference. However, since the drastic declines in abundance of C. engrauliformis and C. grimmi, fishing effort for this species has remained relatively stable in the most recent decade; however, biomass estimates have declined in the most recent eight years available, and despite stable catches, it is currently considered to be overexploited in Iran. Species-specific conservation measures are not in place; however, recommendations to protect and monitor all species of Clupeonella in the Caspian Sea have been suggested, including increased population monitoring and coordinated international efforts. Given that this species is currently widely distributed in the Caspian Sea and abundant throughout a majority of its range, Clupeonella caspia is listed as Least Concern. Increased population monitoring of this species' abundance and fishing effort is highly recommended to detect potential population declines.
habitat: This is a pelagic, euryhaline, schooling species that is known to tolerate marine, estuarine and freshwater environments (Prikhod'ko 1981, Kottelat and Freyhof 2007, Fazli et al. 2007, Coad 2017). The recent observed sea level rise in the Caspian Sea in the most recent 10 – 20 years, has expanded suitable habitat for this species (Mamedov 2006). It is known to a maximum longevity of 6 years (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007). In Azerbaijan, individuals are estimated to reach maturity by the age of 1 (Mamedov 2006) and is known to spawn in open water and near river mouths in the late evening in the Spring from April to July throughout its range (Prikhod'ko 1981, Kottelat and Freyhof 2007, Fazli et al. 2007). This species presumably does not migrate long distances but does move between feeding grounds in the summer and winter, and spawning grounds in the spring and early summer (Coad 2017). It has pelagic eggs that are usually released in water at about 5 metres depth with a salinity of 0.02 - 15 ‰ (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007). Larvae and juveniles remain in shallow water while adults may form schools at deeper depths (30 - 40 metres) in the winter (Coad 2017). This species feeds on zooplanktonic crustaceans (e.g., copepods, mysids) and follows a daily vertical migration moving to surface waters at night and descending to deeper depths in the daylight (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007). In Iran, this species reaches a maximum known standard length of 14.5 cm and a maximum known weight of 19.0 g (Coad 2017).
threats:
This species, similar to the other species of Clupeonella, faces several distinct threats, mostly including impacts from fishing pressure and to a lesser extent, from the invasive ctenophore, Mnemiopsis leidyi. Mamedov (2006) reported that the arrival of M. leidyi resulted in a decreased biomass of zooplankton, the main food resource of this species of Clupeonella, which dropped by a factor of 4–10 between 2000 and 2003. The reproductive biology of this species is different than the other two Kilka species (C. engrauliformis and C. grimmi), which provides some protection from the competition with and predation by M. leidyi (Kideys 2001, Shiganova et al. 2004, Mamedov 2006, Fazli et al. 2017). For example, the northern stock of this species spawns in the Spring when M. leidyi is absent; the southern stock spawns during the coldest time period (between January and February) when M. leidyi biomass and feeding activity is low (Bogutskaya and Naseka 2013, Aladin et al. 2018).

Contrary to the other two Kilka species, the rising sea level observed in the most recent two decades is advantageous to this species as it has expanded the suitable habitat of this species (Mamedov 2006).

Fishing effort for this species has increased substantially since the early 2000s after the introduction of M. leidyi and subsequent decline in abundance of the other two Kilka species. Currently, this species is overexploited in Iranian waters (Aliasghari et al. 2017, Janbaz 2019) and the estimated rate of exploitation has remained relatively stable in the southern Caspian Sea since 2010 at approximately 0.55 (Karimzadeh et al. 2010, Janbaz 2019). Although the biomass of C. caspia has declined from 120,000 tonnes in 2010 to about 80,000 tonnes in 2017 (Janbaz 2019), catches of this species have stabilized in the most recent five years available in in Iranian waters (IFO 2018). Given that Kilka species overall, including C. caspia, have a history of being overexploited throughout the entire range in the Caspian Sea and that biomass estimates from Iran have declined in recent years (~33%) despite stabilized catches in that region during the same time period, there should be some concern regarding the population status of this species. Continued intensive population monitoring of this species (C. caspia) as well as the other two species of Kilka (C. engrauliformis and C. grimmi) is highly recommended.
population:
Status of Kilka in the Caspian Sea

The majority of fisheries landings in the Caspian Sea are attributable to Kilka, the most abundant fishes in the region (Fazli et al. 2009), which includes Clupeonella caspia, C. engrauliformis and C. grimmi. Historically, the majority of Kilka landings were represented by C. engrauliformis, with less than 20 % in contribution by C. caspia and C. grimmi (Fazli et al. 2009, Janbaz et al. 2012, Falahatkar 2015, Coad 2017). Annual harvest of total Kilka catch has shown some fluctuations over time, but overall show a declining trend with evidence to support overexploitation from the majority of its range, including Iran (Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013) and Azerbaijan (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007).

Globally, lumped landings of species of Clupeonella are reported to the FAO in appreciable quantities (averaging roughly 256,000 tonnes per year: FAO 2016); however, we have been unable to determine the extent this species is included in reported landings. Annual catch of three clupeoid species including C. caspia reached a maximum of 423,000 metric tons in 1970, which accounted for roughly 70% of the total fish catch in the Caspian Sea. Overexploitation and the expansion of the invasive ctenophore, Mnemiopsis leidyi, in the early 2000’s resulted in major declines in total biomass and catch of Kilka, as well as a change in the relative abundance of the three species (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007, Fazli et al. 2007, Fazli et al. 2009, Aliasghari et al. 2017, Fazli et al. 2020).

For example, total catch in 1999 peaked at 271,400 tonnes and fishing mortality reached 1.8 y-1 indicating overexploitation (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007).

Additionally, more recent studies from Iran indicate that this species is now considered to be the most common Kilka in the Caspian Sea (Karimzadeh et al. 2010, Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012, Janbaz 2019), accounting for 95.5% of catches in 2017, whereas C. engrauliformis (previously the most abundant) recently represented roughly 3.5% and C. grimmi represented 1.0% in 2017 (Janbaz 2019). 

Furthermore, biomass of all species of Clupeonella declined by a factor a three in Russia, Iran and Azerbaijan between 2000 and 2001, with larger declines seen in 2002 (Shiganova et al. 2004). By 2002, M. leidyi reached critical biomass levels in important commercial areas jeopardizing fishing industries in the Caspian Sea, including Kilka, which was the main commercial fishery for all Caspian countries (Shiganova et al. 2004). Kilka abundance in Iranian waters declined from roughly 10 – 15 % to 0 – 2 % and fisheries collapsed by approximately 50% in 2 - 3 years following the introduction of M. leidyi (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007, Coad 2017).

Azerbaijan

In Azerbaijan, total Kilka catches declined from 18,500 – 5,100 tonnes (2000 – 2004) representing a 72% decrease in 5 years (Mamedov 2006). Recruitment failure in 2001 has been attributed to the invasion and spread to the ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007) and resulted in an increase in the average age of Kilka stock and a large decline in total Kilka abundance (Mamedov 2006).

Iran

The vast majority of available data regarding the status of Kilka in the Caspian Sea refer to Iranian waters, which likely represents less than 50% of all Kilka in the Caspian Sea. However, there is no reason to believe that it is not representative of the entire region. Since 1999, total landings of Kilka in Iran have declined from 95,000 (Fazli, 2011) to 22,602 tonnes in 2017, representing an approximate 76.2% overall (IFO 2018).

Additionally, changes to biological characteristics of all species of Kilka, especially C. engrauliformis, were reported in areas impacted by M. leidyi (Parafkandeg Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012) including a sharp decrease in weight, length and condition individuals (Shiganova et al. 2004). 

Specific information regarding the status of the Common Kilka, Clupeonella caspia

This species is reported as abundant along the shores of the northern and western Caspian Sea (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007).

Azerbaijan

The relatively recent (past 20 years) observed sea level rise in the Caspian Sea has reportedly expanded suitable habitat for this species and catches of this species now account for roughly 14 – 29% of total Kilka catch in Azerbaijan waters, compared to less than 1% in the 1970s (Mamedov 2006).

Iran

Species-specific population data are primarily available from Iran, where C. caspia has increased in abundance in recent years. Overexploitation of Kilka stocks and the introduction of M. leidyi in 1999 resulted in major reported declines in biomass, catch and CPUE of the two other Kilka species, C. grimmi and C. engrauliformis. However, this species has not been as negatively impacted by the invasive ctenophore as the other two species of Kilka given a slightly different ecology, such as spawning and feeding behavior and seasonality (Karpyuk et al. 2004, Bogutskaya and Naseka 2013, Aladin et al. 2018). Therefore, catches of this species, C. caspia, have increased in recent years from less than 1% in the 1990s to more than 95% of current total Kilka catch, making this the most commonly caught Kilka (Karimzadeh et al. 2010, Aliasghari et al. 2017, Janbaz 2019). In the most recent 10 years available (2008 – 2017) catches of this species in Iran have increased from roughly 16,006 tonnes in 2008 to 22,602 tonnes in 2017 (41% increase), but have remained stable in the most recent five years (IFO 2018). Within the same 10 year time window, this species has represented between 95 and 99% of total Iranian Kilka catches (Janbaz 2019). 

Given the substantial declines in abundance of the other two Kilka species within the Caspian Sea, effort for this species has increased in the most recent 20 years (Karimzaheh et al. 2010). Therefore, increasing catches may not truly represent an increase in abundance of this species. The biomass of C. caspia increased from about 25,000 tonnes in 1997 to near 120,000 tonnes in 2010, but declined to about 80,000 tonnes in 2017 (Janbaz 2019), which represents over a 2-fold increase overall, but a decline in biomass of approximately 33% in the most recent 8 years. Despite that this species is not as negatively impacted by the invasive ctenophore relative to the other two Kilka species, Kilka overall, have a history of being overexploited throughout the entire range in the Caspian Sea, and therefore, there is some concern regarding the true population status of this species in light of increased fishing pressure.
range: This species is distributed in the Caspian Sea and the lower reaches of Volga, Ural and possibly Terek (Kottelat and Freyhof 2007). It is known to occupy a depth range between 0 - 100 metres but can be commonly found at depths less than 50 - 70 metres (Coad 2017).
useTrade:
This species supports major commercial fisheries throughout many regions of the Caspian Sea. This species is caught at nighttime using underwater electric lights and fish pumps (Fazli et al. 2009, Aliasghari et al. 2017). 

Azerbaijan is traditionally the most important area for commercial capture of Kilka species in the Caspian Sea (Mamedov 2006). This species is mostly targeted in the southwestern part of the Caspian sea around the Borisov shoal at depths of  30–56 m (1.5–3%) and over the Kornilov - Pavlov shoal at depths of 46–97 m (1.5–3.5%: Mamedov 2006).

In Iran, this species is commercially targeted; catches of all Kilka species are mainly concentrated along the Babolsar and Anzali coasts (Fazli et al. 2007, Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012). Previously in 2008, this species was considered to be overexploited in the southern Caspian Sea with an estimated exploitation rate at 0.55 (Karimzadeh et al. 2010). More recently, the exploitation rate for this species was again estimated to be 0.55 in the southern Caspian Sea and is considered to be overexploited (Janbaz 2019). 

In general, this species is used in local fishmeal industries of Iran. It is also consumed smoked, salted, canned in sauce and oil, and well as marinated, according to a traditional recipe and seasoned with fruits, herbs and vegetables (Alavi-Yegaheh et al. 2017).
conservationActions: No known species-specific conservation measures are in place. In a report prepared for the Caspian Environment Programme in 2001, suggestions of fishing limitations, lab studies and monitoring were made as measures to combat the Mnemiopsis problem. Aliasghari et al. (2017) recommends the increased attention, effort and monitoring of population levels, fishing pressure and influence of M. leidyi on C. grimmi. Further recommendations have been made for increased coordinated international effort needed to implement immediate management of Kilka stocks in the Caspian Sea (Fazli et al. 2009, Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013). It has also been suggested that all catches of the three species of Clupeonella must be restricted during spawning periods (Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013). Given that the most recent (2020) biomass estimates of the other two species of Kilka (C. engrauliformis and C. grimmi) have declined substantially over the past 20 years (> 95%) in Iranian waters (Fazli et al. 2020), there is concern for the population status of this species (C. caspia). The continued increase of intensive population and exploitation monitoring are highly recommended to detect potential declines.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (CR) because its current extent of occurrence and area of occupancy are under 10 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from only one locality, and there is continuing decline in the extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, extent and quality of habitat, number of subpopulations and the number of mature individuals. An estimated 98% of the montane dry forests where this species lives have been lost due to deforestation. The number of mature individuals in the one remaining subpopulation is estimated to be less than 100.
habitat: It is a diurnal riparian species that inhabits streams and surrounding humid microhabitats of dry mountain forests (La Marca et al. 2018). It breeds during the wet season. Eggs are laid in the leaf litter, and the male protects them until they hatch. Once they hatch, the male carries the tadpoles on his back and releases them in small pools of the streams, where they complete their larval development.
threats:
The main ongoing threats to this species are habitat loss and habitat fragmentation due to agriculture. The town of Mucuchíes and its vicinity, where this species occurs, has crops and aquaculture that have not only modified the dry forests, but have also polluted water sources with fertilizer and pesticide effluents. In addition, abstraction of surface water for irrigation is a common practice. As a result, the habitat where the only known subpopulation is found goes through a severe drought every year during the driest months. Of an area of 28 km2 formerly occupied by dry forests, 98% has been lost due to deforestation (La Marca et al. 2018).

Pathogens and parasites may be an additional burden to this species. Specimens collected for museum samples and for an ex situ project showed a high load of nematodes (Castellanos-Montero and Rojas Runjaic, pers. obs., La Marca et al. 2018). The presence of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis in the species is unknown but constitutes an additional and important threat as this pathogen has been detected in several amphibian species of the Venezuelan Andes (Lampo et al. 2008).
population: Exhaustive surveys of its former habitats, including those where it was abundant in the past, failed to detect this species (Castellanos-Montero, La Marca and Rojas-Runjaic pers. comm. 2020). Most populations disappeared between fifteen and twenty-five years ago (La Marca et al. 2018). From seven known subpopulations, only one can still be found and the number of mature individuals in that population has been estimated to be less than one hundred.
range: This species is known from an area of dry forest (28 km2) around the town of Mucuchíes in the Venezuelan Andes, Mérida state, from 2,270 to 3,240 m asl (La Marca et al. 2018). Only 2% of the forest habitat is estimated to remain and the area of occupancy is only 4 km2, and the extent of occurrence is only 9 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of use or trade for this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
Its range does not overlap with any protected area. A captive-breeding plan for the species has been conducted since 2017 at the Rescue of Endangered Venezuelan Amphibians Center (REVA). The ex-situ program started with an initial stock of thirty founder specimens (La Marca et al. 2018). Some awareness activities have been executed by REVA in Mérida city (Mérida, Venezuela) and through social networks.

Conservation Needed
Continue efforts to reproduce the species in captivity for future re-introductions into adequate habitats. Preservation of germoplasm banks and effective forest preservation and habitat restoration where the species can still be found. Education programs aimed at building awareness and community engagement.

Research Needed
Continued population monitoring of remnant populations is needed to detect changes in abundance and contractions in its geographic distribution. Habitat quality and prevalence of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis needs to be closely monitored. An action plan for the conservation of this species is recommended, given its threat status.

rationale: This species is suspected to be decreasing at a moderately rapid rate.  It is therefore classified as Near Threatened.  Should new information suggest these declines are occurring more rapidly it would warrant uplisting; it almost meets the requirements for listing as threatened under criteria A2abce+3bce+4abce.
habitat: The species shows a preference for breeding on wet natural grasslands (Trolliet 2003), meadows and hay meadows (del Hoyo et al. 1996) with short swards (Hayman et al. 1986, Devereux et al. 2004) and patches of bare soil (Johnsgard 1981) at low altitudes (Hayman et al. 1986) (less than 1,000 m) (Snow and Perrins 1998).  It will also breed on grassy moors, swampy heaths, bogs and arable fields (Johnsgard 1981, del Hoyo et al. 1996).  The nest is a shallow scrape in short grass vegetation (del Hoyo et al. 1996).  During the winter the species utilises large open pastures for roosting (del Hoyo et al. 1996) and forages on damp grassland, irrigated land (Urban et al. 1986), stubble and ploughed fields (del Hoyo et al. 1996), riverbanks, lake shores, fresh and saline marshes, drainage ditches, estuaries and mudflats (Africa) (Urban et al. 1986).  Its diet consists of adult and larval insects (e.g. beetles, ants, Diptera, crickets, grasshoppers, dragonflies, mayflies, cicadas and Lepidoptera), spiders, snails, earthworms, frogs, small fish (Africa) and seeds or other plant material (Africa) (Urban et al. 1986, del Hoyo et al. 1996).  Most populations of this species are fully migratory and travel on a broad front out of Europe although some breeding populations in more temperate regions are sedentary (del Hoyo et al. 1996, Snow and Perrins 1998).  The species breeds from April to July (Hayman et al. 1986) in solitary pairs (del Hoyo et al. 1996) although pairs may also nest close together in optimal habitat (Johnsgard 1981, Trolliet 2003).
