threats: This species suffered past declines as a result of land-use intensification, wetland drainage and egg collecting (del Hoyo et al. 1996).  Land-use intensification remains a problem: today it is threatened by reduced breeding productivity as a result of intensifying and changing agricultural practices (del Hoyo et al. 1996), especially the improvement of grasslands (e.g. by drainage, application of inorganic fertilizers and reseeding) (Baldi et al. 2005), increased growing of "winter-crops" (see Eggers et al. 2011), and loss of field margins and semi-natural habitat.  Important migratory stop-over habitats for this species on the Baltic Sea coastline are threatened by petroleum pollution, wetland drainage for irrigation, land abandonment and changing land management practices leading to scrub overgrowth (Grishanov 2006).  Clutch destruction may also occur during spring cultivation (using machinery) on arable fields (del Hoyo et al. 1996).  The species is susceptible to avian botulism so may be threatened by future outbreaks of the disease (Hubalek et al. 2005), and may suffer from predation and nest predation by native and introduced predators (e.g. European Hedgehog Erinaceus europeaus on some islands [Jackson 2001], corvids, herons, gulls, foxes [M. Sorrenti in litt. 2016]).  The species is hunted for commercial use (to be sold as food) and for recreational purposes in Iran (Balmaki and Barati 2006), and is hunted in France, Greece, Italy and Spain (Trolliet 2003).
population: The global   population is estimated to number c. 5,600,000-10,500,000 individuals   (Wetlands International 2012).  The European population is estimated at 1,590,000-2,580,000 pairs, which equates to 3,190,000-5,170,000 mature individuals (BirdLife International 2015).
range: The species breeds from Europe, Turkey and north-west Iran through western Russia and Kazakhstan to southern and eastern Siberia, Mongolia and northern China.  It winters from western Europe, the east Atlantic islands and North Africa through the Mediterranean, Middle East and Iran across northern India to south-east China, the Korean peninsula and southern Japan (Wiersma and Sharpe 2015).
conservationActions:
Conservation and Research Actions Underway
CMS Appendix II. EU Birds Directive Annex II.  Bern Convention Annex III.  Management of habitat for this species occurs in several European countries and agro-environment schemes are in place in France, the Netherlands and the U.K. (Petersen 2009) although they have been shown to not always be effective (Breeuwer et al. 2009).  A European management plan was published in 2009 (Petersen 2009), and a management plan for meadow birds is underway (M. Sorrenti in litt. 2016).

Conservation and Research Actions Proposed
Ensure incentives are in place for landowners to restore and manage suitable habitat as well as reduce pesticide use.  Continue research to find the most appropriate land management practices fro this, and other species (e.g. Chiron et al. 2010, Eggers et al. 2011, Peach et al. 2011, MacDonald et al. 2012).  Reduce hunting pressure, record reliable bag statistics and create awareness campaigns, targeted at hunters, about the decline of this species.  Develop management schemes to reduce predation as well as monitoring and research programmes to inform conservation measures (Petersen 2009).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide range and the localized nature of threats, and because it occurs in a number of protected areas.
habitat: This is a diurnal species of tropical rainforests. It is found in premontane and lowland areas, and sometimes in open habitats (C. Arredondo and J. Daza pers. comms. 2013). It is an egg-laying species, and its prey includes amphibians.
threats: There is a possible threat to this species in parts of Central America, and particularly in Panama, from a loss of food sources through amphibian declines within its range, but it is unlikely that this is more than a localized threat. It is also threatened by conversion of land to agricultural use (including pasture).
population: This species is uncommon, but not rare, at least in Ecuador (D. Cisneros pers. comm. 2013). It appears to be known from numerous records in Colombia (IZN). There is a suggestion that subpopulations of this species may have declined locally in Panama with the loss of amphibian prey, but Chironius species are typically dietary generalists and, in South America, amphibian declines are confined to higher elevations where this species is absent.
range: This species is found from Honduras to Colombia's Magdalena Valley along the Atlantic versant, and from the Pacific slope of central Costa Rica through the Pacific lowlands of Colombia to Ecuador (Savage 2002). Elevational range in Central America extends from sea level to 1,600 meters (Wilson and Johnson 2010).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded to any significant degree.
conservationActions: It is found in a number of protected areas.

rationale: This species is confined to three small islands where, despite its adaptation to artificial habitats, its population is suspected to be under threat as a result of successive droughts and an increasing human population. Its future on one island, in particular, is precarious, and the overall population trend is uncertain. The discovery of a relatively large population on Fogo, where it occurs commonly in plantations and crops, suggests that it may be less threatened than previously feared, and a re-assessment of its extent of occurrence using a minimum convex polygon means that the species now warrants listing as Vulnerable.
habitat: Its original habitat was probably scrub on mountain slopes and reedbeds in valleys (Hazevoet 1993). It is now found in a broad range of habitats up to 1384 m (H. Batalha  in litt. 2016). The habitats occupied at lower elevations include well-vegetated valleys (especially with patches of reeds), reedbeds, woodland, agricultural areas, and gardens in villages and small towns, notably near running water (Hazevoet 1995). In 2004, a population in the interior of Santiago was noted inhabiting Eucalyptus forest with dense, bushy undergrowth at 800-1000 m (J. Hering and H. Hering in litt. 2004). On São Nicolau, it inhabits small, dense stands of cane Arundo donax along dry riverbeds, often with shrubs and fruit trees (Hazevoet et al. 1999). On Fogo, it inhabits coffee plantations with scattered fruit trees and maize fields with coffee bushes in areas characterised by narrow, shrub-filled ravines at 490-950 m, and the forest of Mount Velha (Hering and Hering 2005, Hering and Fuchs 2009, H. Batalha in litt. 2016). It may also in habit cultivated areas around dams (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). It breeds mainly in August-November, but the breeding season may be extended in response to local rainfall (Hazevoet 1995).
threats: Habitat loss due to the combined effects of successive droughts and an increasing human population may be responsible for the population decline and restriction of its distribution on Santiago (C.J. Hazevoet in litt. 2000). This is almost certainly the cause of its decline on São Nicolau and extinction from Brava, where continuing desiccation has restricted agricultural productivity (Hazevoet 1993). In addition, disease and enviromental catastrophies are potential threats to these island populations (Hazevoet et al. 1999). A recent forest fire on Fogo destroyed a large part of inaccessible forest where the species possibly existed (H. Batalha in litt. 2016), and so forest fires, and any future increase in fire frequency could be very harmful to this species. The removal of invasive plant species, such as reed removal by farmers on S. Nicolau, could possibly reduce the available habitat for this species in areas where there is no natural habitat (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). There is suspicion that it may be predated by birds (e.g. kestrel, crows), possibly rats and even humans (H. Batalha in litt. 2016).
population: The population was estimated at c.500 pairs in the early 1990s, and was thought to number 1,000-1,500 birds based on its known range in 2007 (C. J. Hazevoet in litt. 2007). However, conservative estimates of 500 pairs on Fogo mean that the total population is likely to be higher, likely numbering 1,500-2,000 mature individuals, roughly equivalent to 2,200-3,000 individuals in total.  Full censuses were never carried on Fogo or Santiago. The numbers on Santiago could be higher than previously thought because the bird is now known to occur in all vegetated areas of the island, whereas in the 1990s it was thought to be absent from the north of the island (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). On Fogo, a volcanic eruption in 2014 does not seem to have affected the extent of area occupied by the bird, but the bird is absent from areas where it had been previously found on the forest of Monte Velha following the forest fire of 2015. However, the size of the birds’ territories is unknown, and could be larger than in closely related species; this means that the numbers estimated based on replies to playbacks may or may not correspond to the actual numbers (in recent surveys, the same colour-ringed bird replied to playback lures from locations that could have considered two adjacent territories [H. Batalha in litt. 2016]). Surveys on S. Nicolau in three occasions in 2014 and 2016 found 12 – 13 territories each time, and the real number is not likely to be much higher.  There are probably a minimum of 20 birds and a maximum of 50 on that island.
range:
Acrocephalus brevipennis was once believed to be confined to Santiago, Cape Verde Islands, where it was though to be locally distributed. It has most likely died out on Brava (no records since 1969 and formerly scarce) and was believed to have died out on São Nicolau (where it was formerly numerous). However, a previously unreported specimen collected on São Nicolau in October 1970 was discovered in the collection of the Centro de Zoologia, Lisbon, providing the impetus for a thorough search of the island (Hazevoet 1999a) and, in 1998, surveys located eight territories confined to the north-west of the island (though its long-term prospects for survival here are poor) (Hazevoet et al. 1999). In October 2004 a population was discovered on Fogo, and it has since been found to be widespread across the northern half of the island between 200-975 m, with the total population on the island conservatively estimated at 500 pairs (Hering and Hering 2005, Hering and Fuchs 2009). In addition, the species may have formerly occurred on Santo Antão (Hazevoet 1995). On Santiago, the species was recently reported from Tarrafal, far to the north of the species's known range (C.J. Hazevoet in litt. 2007).  The total population was estimated at c.500 pairs in the early 1990s (Hazevoet 1995), and thought to number 1,000-1,500 birds based on its known range in 2007 (C.J. Hazevoet in litt. 2007). However the discovery of relatively large numbers on Fogo means that the total is probably considerably higher.

Surveys to detect this species were carried out in 2013, 2014 and 2016 in a joint project between the University of East Anglia, UK, and Cape Verde Natural Parks of Fogo (Fogo), Serra Malagueta (Santiago) and Monte Gordo (S. Nicolau). Currently, the bird is known to be absent from Brava and Santo Antão (Batalha et al. 2016); anectodal reports could not be verified despite extensive searches and could have consisted of vagrant birds (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). On Fogo, it can be found in densely vegetated areas between 299 and 1384m, including coffee plantations, inaccessible ravines covered in invasive Lantana camara and Furcrarea spp., and the forest of Monte Velha (Batalha et al. unpublished data). On Santiago, it can be found in densely vegetated areas across the island, between 6 and 1,039 m, and in various habitats, from lowland plantations (e.g., Praia, Cidade Velha, Chão Bom, Achada Tenda, Pedra Babejo) to mountain forests (Serra Malagueta and Monte Tchota), and sugar cane plantations in Praia to Prosopis spp. shrub thickets in Tarrafal (Batalha et al. unpublished data). On S. Nicolau, however, territories seem to be confined to a central humid area comprising part of the Natural Park of Monte Gordo and the valleys of Queimadas, Fragata and Covoada, between 162 and 733m (Batalha et al. unpublished data). Extensive, thorough surveys located only 12-13 confirmed territories, either in reed patches or mango trees, so the actual number is not likely to be higher than 20-30 in the entire island of S. Nicolau (Batalha et al. unpublished data). The bird is not present either in the forest of Monte Gordo, on the plantations of Fajã or in the far-east Prosopis spp. thicket of Carriçal (Batalha et al. unpublished data). Genetic data confirm that there have been no recent colonisations or re-colonisations of either of the islands (Batalha et al. 2016).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
Wildlife Protection Laws, proposed in the late 1980s, have still not materialised and, as of 2007, the species still has no legal protection (C.J. Hazevoet in litt. 2007). It is found in three protected areas: Parque Natural do Fogo, Parque Natural da Serra Malagueta and Parque Natural de Monte Gordo. It is considered a CITES species by national authorities, and any work conducted in the natural parks is subjected to permission by the local authorities. There is regular monitoring on Natural Parks of Fogo and Serra Malagueta, and on S. Jorge dos Órgãos. There is also a monitoring scheme in place at Natural Park of Monte Gordo, but it has been irregular over the last few years due to the lack of specialised staff (H. Batalha in litt. 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Encourage local farmers on São Nicolau to plant stands of A. donax cane amongst their fruit trees, by means of agricultural subsidies, to increase the area of available habitat (however, this would be extremely difficult to implement) (Hazevoet et al. 1999). Carry out large-scale and long-term education and information programmes, directed at both the local authorities and general public (Hazevoet 1999b); especially programmes targeting children and farmers, which are the sectors of the population which are most in contact with this bird (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). Carry out directed censuses on Santiago, Fogo and S. Nicolau, to better assess current population numbers.  Investigate what threats it faces (Hering and Hering 2005); especially investigate predation threats, diseases, pathogens and parasites, and the possibility of occurrence of inbreeding depression. Conduct research into possible conservation actions (Hering and Hering 2005), and investigate the possibility/benefit of using genetic restoration to increase number of birds and genetic diversity on the population of S. Nicolau (Batalha et al. 2016, H. Batalha in litt. 2016). Focus research efforts on the recently discovered population on Fogo (Hering and Hering 2005), and build partnerships with Cape Verdean Universities, especially the branches of Santiago, to better study this species (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). Research could include studying diet requirements, breeding behaviour, age at first breeding, breeding success, fledging success, recruitment, adult survival and other basic biological parameters; assess the bird’s adaptation to human-altered habitats; and further research into the species's habitat requirements (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). This may involve investigating the species’s association with dams, which are currently being built on several locations on Santiago, and its association with invasive plant species (e.g., Lantana, Furcrarea, Arundo, Prosopis spp.); which should be considered when planning conservation actions aimed at eradicating invasive species (as previously done on Natural Park of Serra Malagueta) (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). Assess the benefits of a monitoring ringing plan, especially on the subpopulations that live within the limits of Natural Parks of Fogo, Serra Malagueta and Monte Gordo (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). Ensure regular monitoring of the population on S. Nicolau and investigate the extent of local adaptation in all populations (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). Consider expanding the limits of the Natural Park of Monte Gordo to include part of the valley of Canto Fajã, where the bird lives in reed patches which are currently regularly cut by local farmers (in a way that would preserve the livelihood of local farmers as well), and work together with farmers and local people to increase local agriculture, which would benefit both the bird and the people (H. Batalha in litt. 2016). Work together to exchange scientific knowledge and increase conservation capacity of national and local stakeholders (H. Batalha in litt. 2016).

rationale: This species is assessed as Vulnerable because of a small and declining population size found on multiple islands, each with a very small population size.
habitat:
Feeds on a variety of insects, often snatching them and feeding on the wing. Typical habitat is Scalesia, Tournefortia, and Zanthoxylum forest (Galapagos Conservation Trust undated).  Breeding takes place during the warm season (December-May).
hey breed during the warm season (December – May), building a cup-shaped nest high up in a tree, using mosses and lichen as nesting material, and laying three eggs each year. - See more at: http://galapagosconservation.org.uk/wildlife/vermilion-flycatcher/#sthash.xT04kYrX.dpufhey breed during the warm season (December – May), building a cup-shaped nest high up in a tree, using mosses and lichen as nesting material, and laying three eggs each year. - See more at: http://galapagosconservation.org.uk/wildlife/vermilion-flycatcher/#sthash.xT04kYrX.dpufhey breed during the warm season (December – May), building a cup-shaped nest high up in a tree, using mosses and lichen as nesting material, and laying three eggs each year. - See more at: http://galapagosconservation.org.uk/wildlife/vermilion-flycatcher/#sthash.xT04kYrX.dpufhey breed during the warm season (December – May), building a cup-shaped nest high up in a tree, using mosses and lichen as nesting material, and laying three eggs each year. - See more at: http://galapagosconservation.org.uk/wildlife/vermilion-flycatcher/#sthash.xT04kYrX.dpufhey breed during the warm season (December – May), building a cup-shaped nest high up in a tree, using mosses and lichen as nesting material, and laying three eggs each year. - See more at: http://galapagosconservation.org.uk/wildlife/vermilion-flycatcher/#sthash.xT04kYrX.dpuf
threats: Potential threats include parasites, disease, changes in land use or the application of pesticides (Wiedenfeld 2006, Merlen 2013)
population: This species is now relatively rare across many islands (e.g. the population on Santa Cruz may not number more than 36 individuals [Wiedenfeld 2006]), and the population size is suspected to be low; placed here in the range of 2,500-9,999 mature individuals.
range: Pyrocephalus nanus is found throughout the Galapagos Islands, Ecuador, apart from San Cristobal. The taxon is possibly extinct on Floreana and Santa Fe (see Wiedenfeld 2006, Merlen 2013, Carmi et al. 2016) and in serious decline on Santa Cruz (Wiedenfeld 2006, Merlen 2013)
conservationActions:
Conservation and Research Actions Underway

No specific actions are known.

Conservation and Research Actions Proposed

Protect remaining habitat. Conduct research to better understand the threats affecting this species.

rationale: Oxleyan Pygmy Perch is assessed as Endangered based on ongoing declines in both abundance and range. Reports of urban development resulting in the total loss of some populations is not uncommon throughout parts of their range and given the ongoing rapid economic growth along Australia's east coast, the trend is likely to continue. The only relatively safe populations are those present in National Park Estates, however, whilst protected from urban and rural development in these areas, increases in droughts and bushfires as a result of climate change also make these populations susceptible to extinction. This species has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 292 km<sup>2</sup> and the population is considered to be severely fragmented and experiencing continuing declines.
habitat: Oxleyan Pygmy Perch inhabit slightly acidic and tannin-stained water in slow flowing pools and backwaters in coastal streams, river channels, lakes and swampy drainages (NSW DPI 2005). Microhabitat selection is for areas where there is a high abundance of in-water structure such as emergent or submerged plants or steep undercut banks fringed by semi-submerged branches and fine rootlets from adjacent land-based trees and scrubs (Knight and Arthington 2008). A small-bodied and relatively short-lived species, Oxleyan Pygmy Perch has been recorded up to a maximum recorded length of 75 mm, and while its exact longevity is unknown, it is thought to only live to around five years of age (Allen et al. 2002). Sexual maturation is reached at 4-5 months when they are around 25-30 mm in length. The species is a protracted serial spawner, with small batches of eggs and larvae produced continually during the breeding season. The breeding season extends from September through to April/May each year (Knight et al. 2007). Males display strong territoriality when breeding, aggressively defending nesting areas from conspecific males and other small-bodied fish species. Nesting areas are associated with aquatic vegetation in which pairs spawn. Eggs are around one mm in diameter and are demersal and slightly adhesive (Knight et al. 2007). Hatching commences at around 50 hrs post-fertilisation, with larvae 2.8-3.4 mm at hatching. Larvae begin feeding exogenously at around day five when 3.9-4.5 mm in length, with full yolk-sac absorption complete by day eight at the earliest and day 12 at the latest (Knight et al. 2007).
threats: Habitat loss and degradation is possibly the most immediate and ongoing threat for Oxleyan Pygmy Perch, with vast areas of wallum heath either gone, or for those areas that remain outside National Park estates, the risk of encroaching urban and rural development (NSW DPI 2005). Other pressures on habitat both past and present include; sand mining; drainage and rechannelling of natural waterways; man-made barriers to fish passage that have resulted in increased fragmentation of local populations; loss of riparian and other vegetation; pollution from urban, agricultural, industrial and recreational activities; bushfires and hazard reduction burning; and water extraction (Knight et al. 2012). The other main threats are the interspecific competition from introduced species such as Eastern Gambusia (Gambusia holbrooki), and while impossible to estimate exact numbers, the illegal removal of potentially large numbers by aquarium collectors. A potentially insidious threat that again is difficult to quantify, is the threat to the genetic integrity of the species as a result of the populations continuing to fragment (Knight et al. 2009).
population: Oxleyan Pygmy Perch has experienced significant range constriction and fragmentation as a result of anthropogenic influences (Allen et al. 2002). The current population is divided into two clear groups; a southern group in NSW encompassing a number of fragmented populations in swamps, streams and lakes along the fringes of the coastline; and a northern group spread across south-east Queensland in similar mainland habitats, as well as on a number on sand islands adjacent to the coast. There is distinct genetic differentiation evident among the Queensland and NSW subpopulations which implies restricted gene flow between river systems and other habitats. However, one of the nine haplotypes detected was distributed over much of the species’ range, suggesting historical connectivity (Knight et al. 2009).
range: Oxleyan Pygmy Perch has a patchy and restricted distribution along the central region of Australia's east coast. It is found in coastal swamps, streams and lakes in lowland wallum heathlands from Tin Can Bay in south-east Queensland (Qld) in the north to Corindi in northern New South Wales (NSW) (Knight 2016). It is also present on a number of sand islands adjacent to the southern Qld coast; Fraser Island, Moreton and North Stradbroke Islands. This species has experienced significant range constriction and fragmentation as a result of urban development and associated loss of habitat (Allen et al. 2002). In NSW, the species is thought to have possibly been up to 200 km further south and up to 50 km further inland in the past compared to where it is now found (Knight 2016). The current distribution is also very disjunct, with no records across a 250 km stretch of coastline of the mainland in the middle of the current range between Rileys Hill in northern NSW and Deception Bay in south-eastern Qld (Knight 2016).
useTrade: There is no legal trade of the species but it is illegally collected by aquarium collectors.
conservationActions: Oxleyan Pygmy Perch is listed as endangered under the Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and the NSW Fisheries Management Act 1994. It is also listed as vulnerable under the Queensland Nature Conservation Act 1992 (NSW DPI 2005). Research into interactions between this species and Gambusia holbrooki is recommended.

rationale:
Syncomistes rastellus has a small geographic range (EOO = 9282 km2) and is known from 1 location. Its current AOO is 56 km2, but this is probably an underestimate of its actual AOO due to low levels of sampling. It is restricted to suitable habitat in a single river system; the Drysdale River Catchment where it is low to moderately abundant.

Habitat quality in this river system is declining due to invasive species (e.g. cattle), causing siltation. Furthermore, as Syncomistes rastellus has a specialised habitat and diet it is probably less resilient to environmental change (Clavel et al. 2011) .
habitat:
Adults prefer deeper, slow flowing sections of rivers and streams in clear to turbid waters, but are also found in shallower habitats. They are generally found over rocky substrates with abundant algal cover. They are often associated with overhanging vegetation and snags. They have been observed schooling in the water column with Syncomistes trigonicus. Juveniles tend to be found in shallower slow flowing habitats as well as riffles. Syncomistes rastellus has been found inhabiting waters up to 34 degrees celsius (Le Feuvre 2017, Shelley et al. 2018). 

The diet of Syncomistes rastellus consists of algae and detritus. Juveniles are meiophagous omnivores and become algivore-detritivores as they grow. Algae and detritus is scraped off rocks and potentially captured from the water column with specialised teeth (Davis et al 2011, Le Feuvre 2017, Shelley et al. 2018). 

Syncomistes rastellus attains sexual maturity at 7-8 cm and eggs are medium sized (approximately 2 mm) and non-adhesive. Breeding occurs over the wet season (generally December to March) (Shelley et al. 2018). This species has an average maximum thermal tolerance of ~37 degrees Celsius (Le Feuvre 2017).
threats:
Current threats to Syncomistes rastellus include the following:

  • Damage to riparian zones. Riparian zones in the Drysdale River are being degraded by introduced species including cattle, horses, donkeys and pigs, and altered fire regimes.  Reduced riparian habitat quality can reduce habitat and shelter for this species, reduce water quality (including increased turbidity and siltation which may affect algal growth, which forms the basis of Syncomistes rastellus’ diet) and increase water temperatures. Syncomistes rastellus is often associated with overhanging riparian vegetation and snags (Le Feuvre 2017), so reducing riparian habitat quality may impact this species disproportionately.

Future threats to Syncomistes rastellus include the following:

  • Instream barriers and flow modification. There is the potential for water extraction and dam construction on the rivers of the Kimberley to supply large-scale agricultural projects. Such developments impact water availability and flow regimes Flow regimes play an important role in life history of Australian freshwater fish, such as opening up floodplains for breeding and feeding, providing vital nutrient inputs and increasing migration. The Drysdale River has been earmarked as one potential site for a major dam to supply water to a major agricultural development (Petheram et al. 2014). It is unknown what the impacts of such developments may be on Syncomistes rastellus.
  • Climate Change. In general, Australian freshwater fish are thought to be resilient to warming, as they have adapted to a highly variable climate (Morrongiello et al. 2011), yet tropical species may be vulnerable to climate change, as they may already approach their thermal limits during hot, dry periods (Pusey et al. 2011, Burrows and Butler 2012). At present, there is limited data on the thermal performance of northern Australian freshwater fish to support this hypothesis (Burrows and Butler 2012). By 2090, air temperatures across northern Australia are predicted to increase by up to 3.7°C and evapotransipiration by up to 10%, depending on greenhouse gas emissions. There is low confidence in predicted change in total rainfall across northern Australia, however extreme rainfall events may become more intense (CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology 2015). Increased air temperature and reduced runoff will lead to increased water temperatures (Webb et al. 2008); if tropical freshwater fish are currently on the edge of their thermal limits and are unable to rapidly adapt to warming climates (Donelson et al. 2011), exploit thermal refuges or move to cooler regions, they will be vulnerable to climate change. Evidence suggests that some Kimberley endemic freshwater fishes may be somewhat resilient to increased water temperatures while others currently live close to their thermal maxima. Thermal tolerance experiments on Syncomistes rastellus found that the species could tolerate temperatures up to 37.4 degrees. This is several degrees higher than the maximum water temperatures currently experienced in the Drysdale River, so this species may have some inherent resilience to climate change (Le Feuvre 2017). However it is unclear how increased water temperatures will affect individual in the long term, the survival of juveniles and reproductive output and other ecological processes in this species. Nothing is known about their adaptive capacity. It is likely that climate change has the capacity to impact this species.
  • Changed land use, including agriculture development and resource extraction. Major agricultural and resource extraction projects have the capacity to impact aquatic environments by reducing water quality (e.g. increased contaminants, nutrients, salinity and turbidity), affecting riparian habitat and increase instream barriers and water extraction. The Drysdale River is relatively accessible and therefore is potentially vulnerable to changes in land use, including resource extraction and irrigated agriculture (Douglass 2013, Petheram et al. 2014). It is unclear how reduced water quality will impact Syncomistes rastellus, however it is likely that increased turbidity may reduce predation success in this species. The impacts of reduced riparian habitat quality and increased instream barriers and water extraction are covered above.
  • Alien species. Alien species have the capacity to greatly alter ecosystems via processes including direct and indirect predation and competition. While the Kimberley region is free from invasive aquatic species (except the Cane Toad), there is the potential for species to rapidly colonise the region. The Drysdale is relatively accessible, so human mediated introductions are possible.
population: Current and predicted population trends are unknown. There is no quantitative analysis on the population size of Syncomistes rastellus, however it is recorded in low to moderate abundance where found (Le Feuvre 2017, Shelley et al. 2018).
range: This species is endemic to the Drysdale River in the Kimberley region of north-western Australia, where it covers almost the entire catchment (Allen et al. 2002, Morgan et al. 2011, Le Feuvre et al. 2016, Shelley et al. 2018). Due to taxonomic uncertainty, previous records of Syncomistes rastellus from other rivers including the Ord and Pentecost rivers were wrongly attributed to this species and were actually specimens of the recently described Syncomistes holsworthi (Buckle et al. 2010, Moore and Hammer 2015, Shelley et al. 2017).
useTrade: There is no known trade or use of this species.
conservationActions:
There are currently no conservation actions for this species. However, approximately 25% of its range is preserved within the Drysdale River National Park. 

This species has a priority 2 ranking (poorly-known species on conservation lands).

rationale: This species is assessed as Endangered based on an Extent of Occurrence of 160 km<sup>2</sup>, a severely fragmented distribution, and continuing decline in the extent and quality of the species' habitat due to intensifying agriculture and the threat of introduced exotic species. There is a plausible future threat of translocated native species.
habitat: McGuigan (2001) suggests moderate to fast flowing waters often with deep pools separated by shallow runs. Surveys conducted from 1994-1997 in Utchee, Fishers and Rankin Creek suggest the fish are found in shallow water (30-40 cm deep) over course gravel, cobbles, rocks and bedrock with low to moderate water flow (Pusey et al. 2001). Some of the lowland creeks have poor water quality owing to agriculture (tea, bananas and cane) and land clearing. Nothing is really known about its habitat requirements or preferences. Similarly, nothing is known about reproduction although it likely follows the typical rainbowfish pattern in the tropics (Pusey et al. 2001). Reproduction likely occurs throughout the year with peak predicted prior to the onset of the wet season. Spawning occurs in association with macrophytes and the eggs have sticky filaments to prevent them from being washed downstream. Eggs hatch in about 5 days. Adults likely eat aquatic and terrestrial insects and their larvae. The distribution overlaps with eels and the Tully Grunter (Hephaestus tulliensis) and other small bodied fishes, but nothing is know about predator-prey interactions.
threats:
This species inhabits a highly restricted range. The area of occupancy is all lowland agriculture with a mixture of sugarcane, tea and bananas which is increasing in intensity. Wide-spread habitat clearance and use of herbicides, pesticides and fertilizers present a significant threat. Habitat degradation is associated with increasing siltation. Introduced paragrass (Brachiara mutica) is also choking many of these streams coincidental with removal of riparian vegetation. Invasive species, including guppies and platies as a competitor and tilapia as a predator, are abundant in these lowland creeks and present direct threats.

Evidence suggests that hybridisation with co-occurring rainbowfish (M. splendida) will threaten this species (McGuigan 2001, Unmack et al. 2016).

The distribution is small and fragmented opening it up to extinction through stochastic events.
population: Sampling conducted between 1994-1997 suggests that this species was considered the most abundant species at those sites where it occurred contributing 54.9% of the total number of fish (Pusey, Kennard and Arthington 2004). McGuigan 2001 considered it the most abundant species at the sampling sites but suggested there were probably less than 1,000 mature fish at each site. The most recent population information suggests they are common but patchily distributed.
range:
This species is restricted to a small range in the Johnstone River in North Queensland, Australia. It was originally identified in a broad-scale analysis of the rainbowfish phylogeny (McGuigan et al. 2000). The original species description includes populations on the Atherton Tablelands, but these are certainly another species (Malanda Rainbowfish) based on mitochondrial DNA (McGuigan 2001, Unmack et al. 2016). 

The distribution is restricted to lowland tributaries of the north and south Johnstone rivers on volcanic soils (Martin and Barclay 2017). It is locally abundant where it occurs. It is important to note that the species does not appear to occupy any of the other creeks in the area nor the main channel of the North and South Johnstone River. The surrounding area is dominated by M. splendida.
useTrade: This species is part of the aquarium trade and these come from a mix of captive breeding and limited wild catch.
conservationActions: This species is not listed under a species specific conservation plan. McGuigan (2001) considered it Vulnerable, and Pusey et al. 2001 considered it secure. It does not occur in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it is widespread, common and there are no major threats.
habitat: This is a tropical freshwater species which inhabits rivers, creeks, swamps, lakes and ponds over rock and mud bottoms. It prefers shelter among longs or undercut banks and occurs in headwaters in hilly or mountainous terrain (Allen et al. 2002).This species is an oviparous benthic spawner, with males guarding the adhesive eggs until they hatch (Allen et al. 2002).
threats: This species is susceptible to epizootic ulcerative syndrome (EUS) and has been adversely impacted by an EUS-like outbreak from a pathogenic disease in Lake Kutubu, Papua New Guinea (Smith et al. 2016). The native fish in that lake are also likely threatened by over-fishing, hydrocarbon projects and introduced species (tilapia and common carp) (Smith et al. 2016).
population: It is patchy but moderately common in northern Cape York Peninsula, Australia (B Ebner pers obs. 2018). In New Guinea it is common above 500m asl (Allen 1991). It is not thought to be decreasing in abundance across most of its range. However this species has transitioned from one of the main species caught by fishers in Lake Kutubu (Papua New Guinea) in 1995-1997, to not being caught at all four months after the peak of the fish kill from an epizootic ulcerative syndrome-like outbreak (Smith et al. 2016).
range: This species occurs in Papua New Guinea and Northern Australia, from Cockatoo Creek to Ducie River in Cape York, Queensland (Allen 1991, Allen et al. 2002).
useTrade: This species is an important food fish in New Guinea (Smith et al. 2016).
conservationActions: This species occurs in some protected areas within Australia.

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern (LC) due to having a large distribution and a mostly stable population. This should not change when the taxonomy has been resolved (Unmack and Dowling 2010).
habitat: This species is a shoal-forming species which is seasonally abundant at some locations. It can be found in shallow water around aquatic vegetation with sandy or gravel substrates. Typically found in slow-moving sections of rivers, small streams, lakes ponds or permanent water bodies (Allen et al. 2002).
threats: Population decline in the southern region of this species range is suspected to be due to increased salinisation, habitat degradation, cold-water pollution, and impacts of alien species.
population: This species is common throughout most of its range but has experienced population decline in the southern regions.
range: This species is found across eastern and northern Australia from the Northern Territory east and south to the Murray-Darling River. The species complex comprises three clades which probably present three discrete species (Unmack and Dowling 2010).
useTrade: This species is not usually used but can be utilised by the aquarium trade and has been bred in captivity (Thompson and Bray 2018).
conservationActions: This species has a large range across eastern and north-eastern Australia and is common in the northern parts of its population. It has experienced a decline in the southern area of its range.

rationale: This species is assessed as Near Threatened. It has a restricted distribution with an area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,512 km<sup>2 </sup>and there are continuing declines in habitat and the AOO due to the continued release of coldwater discharges from reservoirs, sedimentation of streams from unsealed roads and loss of riparian vegetation, which impact spawning and feeding habitats (meeting criterion B2b). However, the species is not severely fragmented and occurs at more than 10 locations so does not meet criterion B1a.
habitat:
Gadopsis bispinosus is a demersal fish that is restricted to cool, clear, upland or montane streams with abundant instream cover, usually in the form of boulders and cobble. It is often found in medium to large streams where there is lower stream velocity. It is generally found in forested catchments, where there is little sediment input to the stream from erosion or land management practices (Sanger 1984, 1990; Koehn 1990; Lintermans 1998, 2007).

It is a nocturnally active species which is usually solitary. Juveniles are often found in large groups among leaf litter and wood debris. Movements are restricted to a relatively small stretch of river over the duration of the life span; the home-range of adult fish is estimated at approximately 15-20 metres (Lintermans 1998, Broadhurst et al. 2011). The home range is larger in reservoirs (Broadhurst et al. 2012).

Breeding is seasonal, with egg-laying commencing in October/November, probably induced by a relatively rapid rise in water temperature. Fecundity is low and is positively correlated with fish length. Females are though to commence breeding in their second or third year. Between 80 and 420 eggs are laid in a single egg mass (Sanger 1990, Lintermans 1998). Spawning sites are on the underside of boulders (O'Connor and Zampatti 2006).
threats: The major threat is sedimentation of streams which smothers food supplies and spawning sites (Lintermans 1998, 2012). Interactions with introduced fish species (such as trout) are also implicated in its decline, with the species now generally found in streams with complex substrates which may act as predation refuges. Trout are regularly recorded as preying on the species, with all life stages of blackfish vulnerable to trout predation (M. Lintermans unpublished data). Loss of flushing flows downstream of impoundments results in excessive sediment accumulation. In some locations, release of hypolimnetic water results in depressed water temperatures which delays spawning, and results in slower growth of juveniles, extending the period that they are exposed to predation from trout (Hall 2005). Clearing of riparian vegetation reduces shading on streams (affecting water temperatures) and also reduces the buffering of sediment input to streams. Populations can be affected by high levels of sedimentation after fires (Carey et al. 2003, Lyon and O'Connor 2008). Two-spined Blackfish were found dead alongside Brown Trout in the lower Howqua river during an extreme heat event in January 2019 (Jason Lieschke pers. comm.). This is believed to be a factor of high water temperatures and low dissolved oxygen levels.
population: This species was only described in 1984, and so historical distribution is largely inferred, but the species is considered to have had historical declines in population abundance or distribution in the ACT and surrounding NSW, determined from evidence based on direct observation, including a comparison of historical and current records (Lintermans 1998, ACT Government 1999). The species was formerly present in the Murrumbidgee and Paddys rivers in the ACT and possibly the Naas and Orroral rivers in the ACT in the 1940-60s (Greenham 1981, Lintermans 1998), but is now absent from these streams. The species has also been extirpated in the Cotter River downstream of Cotter Dam (Lintermans 1998). It is in relatively low abundance in the Goodradigbee River, Jounama Creek, and upper Murrumbidgee rivers in the Canberra region of NSW (M. Lintermans unpublished data), which is unusual as the species is normally abundant where it occurs (Sanger 1990). These low abundances suggest that population decline has occurred but historical population levels are unknown in these streams. In the upper Murrumbidgee River downstream of Tantangara Dam the species is now only present at a single site, and at that site was in very low abundance when last sampled in 1999, with extensive sediment accumulation noted as a result of the lack of flushing flows following construction of Tantangara. In some streams in the ACT and surrounding regions of NSW it is considered to still be relatively abundant including the Cotter River (ACT; Mountain Creek, Swampy Plain River, lower Geehi River, Micalong Creek; M. Lintermans unpublished data). In Victoria, the species is generally considered common in most sites, particularly some of the tributaries of Lake Eildon (Delatite, Howqua, Jamieson and upper Goulburn rivers).
range:
This species is endemic to south-eastern Australia. Its distribution covers a narrow band from north-eastern Victoria, extending through south-eastern New South Wales (NSW) to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), which is at the northern extremity of its range (Lintermans 1998, ACT Government 1999).

An extensive survey of the NSW southern highlands (Lintermans 1998) located G. bispinosus in the following stream systems:
- Upper Murray, including the lower reaches of the Swampy Plains, Tooma and Geehi Rivers;
- Upper Tumut system, including the lower reaches of the Goobarragandra River;
- Goodradigbee River and a tributary Micalong Creek;
- Mountain Creek.
A 1993 record from the Upper Murrumbidgee River between Yaouk and Adaminaby could not be located during further sampling in the mid 1990s. A very small population upstream of Yaouk was found in 1998, and this represents the upstream limit of this species in the Murrumbidgee system, but its continued persistence at this site is unknown. 

In the ACT, the species is now found only in the Cotter River catchment upstream of the Cotter Dam (Lintermans 1998). It was historically present in the Murrumbidgee River, Paddys River, and possibly the Naas and Orroral rivers in the ACT in the 1940-60s (Greenham 1981, Lintermans 1998).

The species is present in a number of streams in Victoria and is found in the Goulburn, Broken, Mitta Mitta, Ovens, Kiewa and upper Murray catchments.

The number of populations of this species has declined since the 1950s in the Canberra region, and is suspected to have declined in several NSW streams as well. The cause of declines is unknown but suspected to be related to sedimentation, changes in habitat quality as a result of water management (coldwater pollution) and interactions with invasive species (trout, Redfin Perch). In Victoria there is no evidence of decline with good abundances persisting in some streams that have traditionally had good abundances, however, it remains in low abundances in some streams. These streams are often warmer and have less flow during drier periods.
useTrade: This species is not targeted by recreational or commercial fishing, or used in aquaculture. Small numbers of fish may be kept by recreational anglers, which are caught as bycatch.
conservationActions: Gadopsis bispinosus was declared a vulnerable species in 1996 in the ACT, but is not listed as threatened in other range jurisdictions. The species has had recovery plans prepared in the ACT in 1999, 2007 and 2018.

rationale: Hypseleotris regalis is assessed as Near Threatened. It has a broad habitat preference but a highly constrained distribution and could face moderate risk in the event of environmental change. Its entire known distribution is within the Prince Regent River National Park with an AOO of 20 km2.
habitat: This species has broad habitat preferences. It is found in still or flowing water in pools and riffles. Hypseleotris regalis occurs across a range of depths and congregates in small to large groups around aquatic vegetation and woody debris, over rocky or sandy substrates (Shelley et al. 2018). It often hovers midwater and also perches on sandstone rocks. This species is likely to be an oviparous benthic spawner feeding on insect larvae and crustaceans, like other members of the genus (Shelley et al. 2018).
threats: This is a very range restricted species, and may see future impacts from invading cane toads in terms of competition for habitat and poisoning through predation of tadpoles or eggs. Pigs and cattle may cause habitat degradation and siltation.
population: This species is locally abundant in parts of the Roe River and lower reaches of the Prince Regent River (Allen et al. 2002). The full extent of its distribution in the Roe is unknown due to limited sampling.
range: This species occurs in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, in two catchments from the Prince Regent River to the Roe River (Hoese and Allen 1983, Allen et al. 2002).
useTrade: There is no information available relating to the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions: Hypseleotris regalis has a highly constrained distribution and could face moderate risk in the event of environmental change. Its entire known distribution is within the Prince Regent River National Park.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence is less than 300 km<sup>2</sup>, the number of locations is not more than 5, and its habitat and population size are subject to declines and extreme fluctuations.
habitat: Habitat includes pools and backwaters of low-gradient creeks and small to large rivers (Page and Burr 2011). This riverine minnow occurs in waters with slow to moderate flow in perennial sections of the Rio Grande and associated irrigation canals (Sublette et al. 1990). Most often it uses silt substrates (much less often sand) and typically occurs in pools, backwaters, or eddies formed by debris piles; larger individuals use a broad spectrum of habitats, including main and side channel runs, but this species rarely uses areas with high water velocities (USFWS 2007). The species most commonly occurs in depths of less than 20 centimetres in the summer and 31- 40 centimetres (median) in the winter; few use areas with depths greater than 50 centimetres (USFWS 2007). Winter habitat tends to be near instream debris piles (USFWS 2007). This is a pelagic spawner that produces thousands of semibuoyant, non-adhesive eggs that passively drift downstream while developing (see USFWS 2007). Developing eggs and larvae drift passively with river currents for about 3-5 days (Platania and Altenbach 1998). Drift distances may extend more than 100 km with elevated river flows during the spring-time spawning period.
threats:
Throughout much of the historical range, the decline may be attributed in part to destruction and modification of habitat due to dewatering and diversion of water, water impoundment (several dams now intersect the historical range), and modification of the river (channelisation). Competition and predation by introduced non-native species, water quality degradation, and other factors may also have contributed to the decline (USFWS 2010). Some of these threats have been reduced since the Rio Grande Silvery Minnow was listed as endangered, but none have been eliminated (USFWS 2010). The population has become fragmented and isolated and is vulnerable to natural and human-caused factors that could further reduce population size (USFWS 2010). Analyses by Alò and Turner (2005) suggest that the genetically effective size in the Rio Grande Silvery Minnow currently is "much smaller than expected based on adult census size; in fact, it is sufficiently small to warrant concern about extinction from genetic factors in the long term."

Survival of the species continues to be threatened by habitat and flow modifications (dewatering, channelization, regulation, and diversion of river flow to provide water for irrigation; diminished water quality caused by municipal, industrial, and agricultural discharges), and lack of suitable aquatic refugia during periods of low or no flow (Bestgen and Platania 1991, USFWS 1994, 2003, 2007, 2010). Drought exacerbates the problem of dewatering of habitat for human uses. Recruitment of young fish into breeding populations may be limited because eggs and larvae are entrained through water diversion structures and are transported downstream into unsuitable nursery habitats (e.g., Elephant Butte Reservoir) (Platania and Altenbach 1998). Additionally, dams may block upstream return to natal sites or prevent recolonization of areas where the species has been extirpated (e.g., Luttrell et al. 1999). It is unlikely that predation is a major factor in the decline of the Rio Grande Silvery Minnow, but it has probably played a minor role, with increasing importance as populations have come under greater stress from other factors (USFWS 2010). Competition and/or hybridization with non-native species in the future could potentially affect the remaining populations of Rio Grande Silvery Minnow (USFWS 2010). A small range makes the species vulnerable to catastrophic events (e.g., loss of surface water) that could wipe out the remaining population (USFWS 2003).

"Although various conservation efforts have been undertaken in the past and others are currently being carried out in the middle Rio Grande, and abundance in recent years is increasing, the threat of extinction of the Rio Grande Silvery Minnow continues because of the high probability of continued drought, the fragmented and isolated nature of currently occupied habitat, and the absence of Silvery Minnows in other parts of the historic range. Additional work needs to be done to conserve this species and the ecosystems upon which it depends." (USFWS 2010).
population:
This species is represented by 1-4 subpopulations; it is known to occur only in one reach of the Rio Grande, which is split by three river-wide dams into four discrete sections (USFWS 2007). Analysis of microsatellite and mitochondrial DNA detected little spatial genetic structure over the current geographic range, consistent with high gene flow despite fragmentation by dams (Alò and Turner 2005). An estimated 90-95 percent of the population is believed to be in the 96 km portion of the Rio Grande downstream of the San Acacia Dam (Ikenson 2002).

Analysis of temporal genetic data indicated that present-day effective population size of the largest extant population of this species (San Acacia reach) was 78 and the ratio of effective size to adult numbers was approximately 0.001 during the study period (1999 to 2001) (Alò and Turner 2005). Thus, the adult population size in this reach, which is estimated to include 90-95% of the total population, appeared to be roughly 78,000.

Abundance of this species exhibits substantial (order of magnitude) fluctuations from year to year (Alò and Turner 2005).

Catch rates (CPUE) declined from the early and mid-1990s through 2003 (USFWS 2007). In 2004 and 2005, abundance of the remaining population (in the middle Rio Grande) increased. In 2004 and 2005, the Rio Grande experienced an increased stream discharge, compared to the extended low-flow conditions seen in 2002 and 2003. Relative abundance of the species declined from approximately 50 percent of the total fish community in 1995 to about 5 percent in 2004 (USFWS 2007).

In December 2008, Silvery Minnows were introduced into the Rio Grande River near Big Bend, Texas, as a nonessential, experimental population (USFWS 2010). More than 2.6 million minnows had been released in the Big Bend region until 2017 and, although some successful reproduction have been observed, sustaining populations have not yet been achieved (Texas Parks and Wildlife 2017).
range: Historical range included the Rio Grande and Pecos River systems, Texas, New Mexico, and Mexico; in the Rio Grande, this species occurred from Española, New Mexico, downstream to the Gulf of Mexico; in the Pecos River it occurred from the Rio Grande to Santa Rosa, New Mexico; it also occurred in the lower Rio Chama and the lower Jemez River, tributaries of the Rio Grande in New Mexico (USFWS 2010). It has never been found in any Mexican tributaries to the Rio Grande, despite extensive collection efforts (Edwards et al. 2003). Currently, the species is known to occur only in one reach of the Rio Grande in New Mexico, a 280 km stretch of river that runs from Cochiti Dam to the headwaters of Elephant Butte Reservoir: this includes a small portion of the lower Jemez River, a tributary to the Rio Grande north of Albuquerque (Sublette et al. 1990, Bestgen and Platania 1991, USFWS 1994, 1999, 2007, 2010, Bestgen and Propst 1996, Dudley et al. 2005). Extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, and population size have declined greatly. Formerly, this was one of the most widespread and abundant species in the Rio Grande basin of New Mexico, Texas, and Mexico, but now the range has been reduced from an estimated 3,862 river-kilometers to only 280 river-kilometers (about 7 percent of the historical range) (USFWS 2010).
useTrade: The species is not used or traded.
conservationActions:
A summarized recovery plan (USFWS 2007) needed the following conservation measures:
  1. Develop a thorough knowledge of the Rio Grande Silvery Minnow's life history, ecology, and behaviour, and the current status of its habitat.
  2. Restore, protect, and alter habitats as necessary to alleviate threats to the Rio Grande Silvery Minnow.
  3. Ensure the survival of the Rio Grande Silvery Minnow in its current habitat and reestablish the species in suitable habitats within its historical range.
  4. Implement and maintain an adaptive management program so that appropriate research and management activities are implemented in a timely manner to achieve recovery of the Rio Grande silvery minnow.
  5. Design and implement a public awareness and education program.
Important factors for recovery of this species include:
  1. Natural flow regimes.
  2. Periodic flood events during spring and summer to initiate breeding.
  3. Appropriate habitat for early life-history stages, including floodplain and other shallow, quiet water environments.
  4. Suitable water quality.
  5. Unimpeded flows to allow for movement of various life stages (USFWS 2007).
Rio Grande Silvery Minnow eggs have been collected from two of the monitoring sites in 2010 and in August 2010, indicating some successful reproduction (Texas Parks and Wildlife Report 2017: Grant No TX-E-169-R).

rationale: Following a large increase in range and population size prior to 1920, recent surveys suggest a steep decline both in abundance and in locations throughout the range. The species is therefore listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: The Evening Grosbeak occurs in northern conifer or mixed forests, but also occupies secondary growth and sometimes urban parks and orchards (Gillihan and Byers 2001). Individuals in the northern part of the range migrate southward as a response to food scarcity and return to the breeding grounds by mid-May (Gillihan and Byers 2001). It mainly feeds on invertebrates (spruce budworms and other larvae), but also on small fruits and seeds (Gillihan and Byers 2001).
threats: The species has been undergoing rapid declines in the last decades (Bonter and Harvey 2008, Ralston et al. 2015, COSEWIC 2016, Rosenberg et al. 2016, Sauer et al. 2017). However, the reasons for decline are not yet identified. It has been suggested that the alteration of habitats, diseases, collisions with windows and the control of its insect prey (e.g. spruce budworm) are potential contributing factors (Gillihan and Byers 2001, Bonter and Harvey 2008).
population: The population size has been estimated at 3.4 million mature individuals (Rosenberg et al. 2016). This equates to 5.1 million individuals in total.
range: The species is found in continental North America, where it occurs from southern Canada through large parts of the U.S.A. to western and southern Mexico. In the 19th century, the species started expanding its range from western U.S.A. northward into Canada and eastward to the Atlantic coast. This range expansion culminated around 1920. It was accompanied by an increase in population size and might be attributable to the spread to Box Elder Acer negundo as an ornamental tree in eastern cities and to peaks in insect abundance, both providing a food source to the species (Gillihan and Byers 2001).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway Listed as Special Concern in Canada (COSEWIC 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed Monitor the population trend and assess potential threats and their impacts on the population size and distribution range.

rationale: This species occurs on only three islets, with invasive species posing a severe future threat that could drive the species to Critically Endangered or Extinct in a very short period of time. Therefore, it is assessed here as Vulnerable.
habitat: The species's range over pelagic water is not well known, but it is assumed that it forages over a large area extending from Guadalupe Island southward to Galapagos (Howell 2012). It feeds mainly on small fish, squid and crustaceans (Carboneras et al. 2018). It breeds in winter (November-April) on three islets nearby Guadalupe islands (Carboneras et al. 2018). Nests are placed in crevices and burrows (Howell 2012). The species is temporally segregated from the co-occurring Townsend's Storm-petrel Hydrobates socorroensis, which breeds at the same sites during summer (May-October) (Howell 2012).
threats: It is likely that a population of Ainley’s Storm-petrel previously existed on Guadalupe island, but was extirpated following the introduction of cats and goats to the main island through predation and trampling of burrows (Aguirre-Muñoz et al. 2011). Mice also occur on Guadalupe (Aguirre-Muñoz et al. 2011) and are a known nest predator of other petrels (Bicknel et al. 2009). However, there are no invasive species known on the three small islets off Guadalupe on which Ainley’s Storm-petrel is currently breeding. Although little research currently takes place on the islets surrounding Guadalupe, it has been shown that disturbance by investigators have significant negative impacts on the breeding success of the closely related Leach's Storm-petrel Hydrobates leucorhous (Blackmer et al. 2004) and thus should be considered a potential threat.
population: In Brooke (2004), the population size for both H. cheimomnestes and H. socorroensis combined was placed at 5,000 pairs (i.e. 10,000 mature individuals). Howell (2012) suggests that the population for this taxon alone is likely no more than a few thousand individuals. Therefore, the population size may be best placed in the range 2,500-9,999 mature individuals.
range: Hydrobates cheimomnestes is only known to breed from November/December to April/May on the islets of Islote Negro, Islote Afuera and Gargoyle Rock by Guadalupe Island, Mexico (Howell 2012). The pelagic distribution of the species is not well known; it is assumed that during the non-breeding season the species ranges from the Baja California Peninsula southward to the Galapagos Islands (Howell 2012, Carboneras et al. 2018).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
None known.

Conservation Actions Proposed
Continue biocontrol to avoid the spread of invasive predators to the islands. Investigate the pelagic distribution range. Monitor the population trend.

rationale: This species is widespread in the Indo-West Pacific and also occurs in the eastern Pacific Ocean. It is known to occur off the coasts of Iraq, Kuwait and Abu Dhabi, where it is considered to be common. Additional population information is not available. This species is of high commercial importance to the fisheries industry as a game- and bait-fish throughout its distribution. Fisheries pressure is increasing in several countries and it is a major aquaculture species in the Philippines, Indonesia and Taiwan. Although this species is not known to face any major threats at this time, there is little information on the population size or trend of this species and fisheries pressure is increasing. There are no known, species-specific conservation measures in place for this species currently. However, there are several marine protected areas throughout its distribution and it has been recorded from at least one within the Persian Gulf. Therefore, Chanos chanos is currently listed as Least Concern. However, more research is currently required to assess the status of various subpopulations from throughout its widespread range.
habitat:
This is a marine species entering estuaries and rivers (Seegers et al. unpub.). It is a benthopelagic, amphidromous species that occurs in tropical waters between depths of 1 to 30 m (Shao and Lim 1991, Jeyaseelan 1998, Riede 2004). It is found in offshore marine waters and shallow coastal embayments, also frequently entering estuaries and occasionally penetrating freshwater streams (Allen et al. 2002).

Adults occur in small to large schools near the coasts or around islands where reefs are well developed. Eggs and larvae are pelagic up to two to three weeks. Older larvae migrate onshore and settle in coastal wetlands (mangroves, estuaries) during the juvenile stage, or occasionally enter freshwater lakes. Juveniles and subadults return to sea where they mature sexually. It spawns only in fully saline water. Larvae eat zooplankton, and juveniles and adults eat cyanobacteria, soft algae, small benthic invertebrates, and even pelagic fish eggs and larvae. It can thrive and grow in water as hot as 32°C (Frimodt 1995) (after Froese and Pauly 2003). The maximum standard length of this species is 180 cm male/unsexed (Lieske and Myers 1994), and the common standard length is 100 cm male/unsexed. The maximum published weight is 14.0 kg and the maximum reported age in 15 years (Bagarinao 1994).

This species spawns in clear, shallow waters above sandy bottoms or coral approximately 30 m from the shore. Females can spawn up to approximately five million eggs which hatch after 24 hours. Larvae then seek out clear, coastal and estuarine waters warmer than 23°C with salinities ranging from 10-32, and abundant phytoplankton. Spawning and fertilisation is nocturnal. The distribution of this species is limited by susceptibility to predation, but temperature is the prime limiting factor (Schuster 1960). Milkfish exhibit nocturnal broadcast spawning possibly more than once a year, and there is no parental involvement after the eggs are released. Spawning is seasonal and my be influenced by the lunar cycle. The spawning season is longer near the equator than at higher latitudes; may be influenced by water surface temperatures (Garcia 1990, Bagarinao 1994).

Larvae are collected from rivers and are grown in culture ponds into juveniles, which are marketed fresh, smoked, canned and frozen. Broodstocks can be raised and spawned in captivity to produce larvae in the hatchery (Bagarinao 1999).

This species is relatively common in large floodplain lakes in northwestern Madagascar.
threats: Overexploitation of larvae for aquaculture and over fishing are threats impacting this species. This species is also susceptible to numerous parasites and bacterial diseases (Regidor and Arthur 1986, Villaluz 1990, Leong 1992, Arthur and Lumanian-Mayo 1997).
population:
No information is available for more than very local stocks. While there is a massive body of research results on this species, this is strongly concentrated on domestic stocks, while wild subpopulations, their trends and threats remain unstudied in most parts of its range. On the other hand, there seem to be also no indication of a strong decline of the wild subpopulations, which might be vulnerable to over fishing.

In the Persian Gulf, Chanos chanos was considered a common species during a survey from waters surrounding Sammaliah Island, Abu Dhabi, UAE and its intertidal lagoons. This survey was conducted from March 2001 to August 2006 with the use of five different fishing methods at different times during the study (Al-Lamy et al. 2012). Landings in UAE have fluctuated but show no trend from 2005-2012. Landings in the last few years may not be reliable. It is considered common off the southeastern coast of Qatar in the winter months.
range: Chanos chanos occurs in the Indo-West Pacific from South Africa, East Africa, Madagascar, the Mascarene Basin, Seychelles, north to the Red Sea and Persian Gulf, northeast to southern Japan, south to Western Australia, New South Wales, and Norfolk Island, east to the Marquesas Islands, north to the Hawaiian Islands and Panama. It is a Mediterranean Sea immigrant. This species also occurs in the eastern Pacific Ocean from San Pedro, California to the Galapagos Islands (Forsskål 1775, Bagarinao 1994).
useTrade:
This species is of major economic importance for aquaculture, especially in Southeast Asia but increasingly also elsewhere. Milkfish are commercially raised for food in the Philippines and Indonesia (Gale 2003). More than a quarter of a million tons of Milkfish are harvested every year in brackish ponds in Indonesia, Taiwan, and the Philippines. They contribute around 60% of the total fish production from aquaculture in Southeast Asia (Garcia 1990). In the Persian Gulf, Chanos chanos is a highly commercial species, utilised by fisheries as a game- and bait-fish. It is also raised in aquaculture (FAO 1992, van der Elst 1993, Garibaldi 1996).

While there are technologies to establish brood stocks, many small scale farmers still depend on wild caught larvae for farmings. This is a potential threat for the species but large scale studies seem to be absent. Milkfish are also caught by coastal fisheries but seem rarely to be a target species.
conservationActions: There are no known, species-specific conservation measures in place for Chanos chanos. Surprisingly little is known about the wild subpopulations of this species and we very strongly recommend an international, large scale research project to gather relevant information. There are several marine protected areas within its distribution, and it has been recorded from the Jubail Marine Wildlife Sanctuary (Krupp and Muller 1994).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is only 2,708 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it is somewhat adaptable to habitat change and it has a presumed large population.
habitat: This is an adaptable species that inhabits both lowland rainforest and rural gardens (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019). It breeds by direct development, and the males have been observed guarding the eggs (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019).
threats: It is an adaptable species that is unlikely to be facing any significant threats. Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea or the Admiralty Islands (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the islands. While there is no known significant impact on closely-related microhylids in Australia, there are records of declines caused by chytridiomycosis on direct-developing species in other families. Therefore, should chytrids be detected on the Admiralty Islands, this species should be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).
population: This species is common and abundant (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019) and its population is believed to be stable.
range: This species is known from sea level to the highest elevations (approximately 718 m asl) across all of Manus Island in the Admiralty Islands of Papua New Guinea (Richards et al. 2015). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,708 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is likely to occur in the Ndrolowa Wildlife Management Area (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019). 

Conservation Needed
Declines due to the arrival of chytrids are known to be rapid and severe. Therefore, a common analogue species should be identified and the capacity for ex-situ conservation (e.g. captive assurance populations and genome banking) should be developed in country. There is a high risk that the introduction of chytrids could be caused by human activities, “enforcing quarantine measures through policy changes, investing in compliance, promoting education, and minimizing risks, including transportation of infected sources” (Bower et al. 2019) is strongly recommended (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: After having undergone moderately rapid declines over the past decades, the declines now seem to have slowed down. The population may now actually be stabilizing, and the rate of decline may not have approached the threshold for Vulnerable for at least five years. The species has therefore been downlisted to Least Concern.
habitat: The species inhabits montane and subalpine coniferous forests. It is found in pine, fir, spruce and aspen forests, preferring dry, semi-arid open areas (Hahn 1996, Clement 2019). During the breeding season, the species occurs between 1,000 and 3,000 m; during the non-breeding season it may also be found in lower elevations in similar habitat and occasionally in urban areas (Clement 2019).
threats: There is little information on potential threats to the species, and in fact its preference for more open habitats suggests that selective, or small-scale, forest clearance should not have too much of a negative impact on the species (Hahn 1996). It has been suggested that climate change could be an important future threat though, as the forests where it occurs are predicted to become drier, with concomitant increases in fire frequency and potential increases in pest infestations (G. Butcher in litt. 2016).
population: Partners in Flight estimate the global population to number 3 million mature individuals (A. Panjabi in litt. 2017).
range: Cassin’s Finch (Haemorhous cassinii) is found in montane coniferous forest in the mountains of North America. It occurs from British Columbia and southern Alberta in western Canada through the Rocky Mountains in the U.S.A., with wintering populations occurring south into northern Mexico (although at lower elevations than during the breeding season) (Clement et al. 1993, Hahn 1996). Migration appears to be erratic and possibly dependent on food supply in the breeding range (Clement et al. 1993, Hahn 1996). Population trends should therefore probably be viewed with some caution due to apparent lack of site fidelity (Hahn 1996).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway

No targeted actions are known for this species, but it is on the watch list as part of the State of North America's Birds (North American Bird Conservation Initiative 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed

Continue to monitor the population and its trends. Determine what the threats to the species are and develop appropriate conservation actions. Work with owners and managers of montane pine forests to ensure that logging practices are beneficial to the species.

rationale: This species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction over the past three generations that approaches the threshold for listing as Threatened. The recent decline may be part of a longer-term fluctuation and the population should be monitored carefully to ascertain whether it shows signs of stabilising.
habitat:
The species breeds on coastal saltmarshes, sand and shingle beaches, dunes, cliff-tops with short grass and occasionally rocky shores, as well as inland along the shores of lakes, reservoirs and rivers or on agricultural grass and cereal fields, often some distance from water (Hayman et al. 1986, del Hoyo et al. 1996). Outside of the breeding season the species is chiefly coastal, frequenting estuarine mudflats, saltmarshes and sandy and rocky shores (del Hoyo et al. 1996). The nest is a shallow scrape on the ground often on raised surfaces (e.g. earth banks) in the open or in short vegetation on cultivated or uncultivated land, cliff-tops, rocky outcrops or clearings in taller vegetation including woods and moorland (Hayman et al. 1986, del Hoyo et al. 1996, Snow & Perrins 1998).

Most populations of this species are fully migratory, inland breeders moving to the coast for the winter (del Hoyo et al. 1996). The species breeds from April to July (Hayman et al. 1986) in solitary pairs or small groups (Flint et al. 1984), during the winter foraging singly or in small groups of up to 10 individuals (Snow & Perrins 1998) and with larger flocks often forming in major bays and estuaries and at roosting sites (Hayman et al. 1986, del Hoyo et al. 1996, Snow & Perrins 1998). When foraging on soft intertidal substrates bivalves and gastropods are the most important food items for this species (del Hoyo et al. 1996). Polychaetes and crustaceans are more important in estuaries however, and molluscs (e.g. mussels, limpets and whelks) are most important on rocky shores (del Hoyo et al. 1996). When inland, prey such as earthworms and insect larvae (e.g. caterpillars and cranefly larvae) are also taken (del Hoyo et al. 1996).
threats:
The main threat to the species is the over-fishing of benthic shellfish and the resulting disappearance of intertidal mussel and cockle beds (Atkinson et al. 2003, Verhulst et al. 2004, Ens 2006, van de Pol et al. 2014). Bait digging has also been identified as a threat through loss of prey species and disturbance to the benthic fauna (van de Pol et al. 2014). The species is also threatened by habitat degradation on its wintering grounds due to land reclamation (for example in the Yellow Sea [Melville et al. 2014]), pollution, human disturbance (Kelin & Qiang 2006) (e.g. from construction work or recreational activities [Burton et al. 2002, van de Pol et al. 2014]), coastal barrage construction (Burton 2006), industrial development including development of ports and oil extraction, oil spills, wind farms (Melville et al. 2014) and reduced river flows (Kelin & Qiang 2006). Rapid and extensive land reclamation is reported from staging and wintering grounds for the osculans population in South Korea and China and large-scale planting of Spartina alterniflora on the coast of eastern China may cause loss of foraging and nesting habitats (Melville et al. 2014). Intensive agriculture including frequent mowing of grasslands and high densities of grazing livestock threatens chicks, eggs and nests and high levels of fertilizers and pesticides can reduce soil invertebrate biomass (van de Pol et al. 2014). A reduction in eutrophication is likely to have contributed to declines in some areas, owing to a loss of food resources (van de Pol et al. 2014, H. Meltofte in litt. 2015). 

Sea level rise leading to increased coastal erosion and flooding is contributing to habitat loss in some areas (Melville et al. 2014, van de Pol et al. 2014).
